Okay, here we go. This is… the big one. The question everyone wants to ask, and the one that's hardest to answer.

It wasn't a quick decision, okay? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, adoption sounds good." It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

The truth is, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not financially stable. I'm still in school. I have dreams and goals that I want to pursue.

And I wanted my baby to have the best possible life. A life that I couldn't provide right now.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were financially secure, who were emotionally ready, who could give them all the things I couldn't. A stable home, a good education, a loving family.

I met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby, and I just… knew. They were kind and compassionate and they seemed genuinely excited about becoming parents. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love.

It was a really hard decision. It still is. There are days when I question myself, when I wonder if I'm doing the right thing. But I know, deep down, that it is.

It's not about me wanting to avoid responsibility. It's about wanting what's best for the baby. It's about giving the baby a chance at a good life.

It's not a happy ending, not in the traditional sense. But it's a hopeful one. And it's a decision that I made with a lot of love and a lot of courage.

It's not easy, talking about it. But it's important. And I hope people can understand. It wasn't about giving up on my baby. It was about giving my baby the best possible start in life. And that's something I can live with. Even if it breaks my heart a little bit.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, how excited they were, how much they already loved this little person they hadn't even met yet… that showed me a different kind of love. A quiet, steady, unwavering kind of love.

And responsibility? It's not just about doing what you're *supposed* to do. It's about owning your actions. It's about facing the consequences. It's about being accountable for your choices.

I was responsible for creating this life. And I was responsible for making the best decision for that life, even if it was a hard one. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

I also learned that love and responsibility aren't always easy. They can be messy and complicated and painful. But they're also incredibly rewarding.

And I learned that you don't have to be perfect to be a good person. You just have to be willing to try. To learn. To grow.

This whole experience forced me to grow up, faster than I ever expected. It forced me to confront my own fears and insecurities. And it forced me to learn what it really means to love and to be responsible.

It's not a fairytale. It's real life. And it's messy and complicated and beautiful all at the same time. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even though it's been the hardest thing I've ever done. It was about learning to love myself, even when I didn't like what I saw.

It also taught me the importance of compassion, of empathy, and of selflessness.

So yeah. My vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey in a profound way. They forced me to grow up, to confront my fears, and to become a stronger, more resilient person.

Honestly? I'm terrified. Absolutely petrified.

My dad… he's a good guy, but he's kinda clueless sometimes. I don't think he'll understand. He'll probably just be angry and disappointed. And I can't handle that right now.

Bren… she's the one I'm most worried about. She's always been so supportive and understanding. But this is… a lot. I don't want to let her down. I don't want to ruin everything.

I've been rehearsing what I'm going to say in my head for days. But every time I try, I just freeze up. I can't find the right words.

I know I need to tell them. I can't keep it a secret forever. But the thought of actually having that conversation… it makes my stomach churn.

I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to prepare myself for the worst. But I'm also hoping for the best. I'm hoping that they'll be understanding. I'm hoping that they'll still love me.

I just… I don't know what's going to happen. And that's the scariest part.

I think I'm going to need a lot of chocolate and a really good playlist to get through this. And maybe a hug from Bren. If she's willing to give me one.

It's just… a really hard thing to do. And I wish it didn't have to be done at all. But it is. And I have to face it. Eventually. Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me want to crawl into a hole and disappear.

Ugh, okay, this is… complicated. It's not that I *don't* trust my dad and Bren. I do. They're amazing. Seriously.

It's just… I don't want to burden them. I feel like I've already put them through enough. Like I've let them down.

My dad, he's always been so supportive of me. He's always encouraged me to be independent and to follow my dreams. And I feel like getting pregnant is the opposite of that. It's like I've ruined his plans for me.

And Bren, she's always been so good at fixing things. At making everything better. And I don't want to be another problem for her to solve. I want to be able to handle this on my own.

I also feel… embarrassed. It's hard to talk about something so personal and so scary. I don't want them to judge me. I don't want them to think I'm irresponsible or stupid.

I know it's irrational. I know they love me unconditionally. But it's hard to let go of those feelings.

I'm also afraid of disappointing them. I want to make them proud. And I feel like I've failed.

So I try to handle things on my own. I try to be strong and independent. I try to pretend that everything is okay.

But it's exhausting. And it's lonely.

I'm learning to let them in, slowly. To ask for help when I need it. But it's a process. It's not easy.

It's just… I don't want to be a burden. I don't want to disappoint them. And I don't want to be judged. It's a lot to deal with, you know? It's a lot. And sometimes, it's just easier to keep it to myself. Even though I know it's not the best thing to do. It's just… hard. Really hard.

Okay, look. This isn't an easy thing to talk about. It's not like I woke up one day and decided, "Oh yeah, adoption, that sounds great!" It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to Bren.

But ultimately, I believe adoption is the best option because it's the most selfless thing I can do.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am, what I want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I wouldn't be able to give the baby the life it deserves.

I want that baby to have a stable home, with parents who are financially secure and emotionally ready. I want that baby to have opportunities that I can't provide.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited, and they're so prepared. They're going to be incredible parents.

And honestly, knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for by them… that gives me peace of mind. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it… okay.

It's not about me not wanting the baby. It's about wanting what's best *for* the baby. And I truly believe that's with Mark and Vanessa.

It's a hard decision, and it's one that I'll probably grieve for a long time. But I know it's the right decision. It's the most loving thing I can do.

And it allows me to focus on my own future, to finish school, and to pursue my dreams. I want to make something of my life, and I want to be a good role model for the baby, even from a distance.

So yeah. That's why I believe adoption is the best option. It's not about what I want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's all that matters. It's a tough love, but it's love nonetheless. And I'm trying to be strong, for everyone involved.

Okay, this is… the big one. This isn't something I take lightly. It's not about finding perfect people, because nobody's perfect. It's about finding people who are going to give my baby the best possible life.

First and foremost, I want them to be **kind.** Genuinely kind. Not just putting on a show for me, but being kind to each other, to strangers, to everyone. I want my baby to grow up in a loving and supportive environment.

I want them to be **stable.** Financially, emotionally, everything. I want them to be able to provide for my baby's needs, and to give them a sense of security.

I want them to be **open-minded.** I want them to be accepting of all kinds of people, and to encourage my baby to be themselves. I don't want them to try to mold my baby into something they're not.

I want them to be **patient.** Raising a child is hard work. I want them to be able to handle the challenges with grace and understanding.

And I want them to be **fun.** I want them to be able to laugh and play and enjoy life. I want my baby to grow up in a home that's filled with joy and happiness.

I also want them to be willing to be honest with my baby about their adoption story. I want them to be open and transparent about where my baby came from.

Mark and Vanessa… they seem to have all of those qualities. They're kind, they're stable, they're open-minded, they're patient, and they're fun. They've been so supportive and understanding throughout this whole process.

It's still scary, letting go. But knowing that my baby is going to be loved and cared for by them… that makes it a little bit easier. It's not about finding a replacement family, it's about giving my baby the best possible start in life. And I think Mark and Vanessa can do that. I really do. It's the hardest decision I've ever made, but I think it's the right one.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… the big one.)

Okay. It's not going to be easy. I know that. I'm not pretending it will be. There are going to be days when I'm completely heartbroken. Days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry.

But I'm trying to prepare myself. I'm talking to a therapist, which Bren insisted on. It's… helpful. She helps me process my feelings and develop coping mechanisms.

I'm also trying to focus on the positive. On the fact that I'm giving this baby a chance at a good life. A life that I can't provide right now.

I'm staying in contact with Mark and Vanessa. We're having regular meetings, and they're keeping me updated on how things are going. It's comforting to know that they're loving and caring for the baby.

I'm also allowing myself to grieve. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to feel lost. It's okay to miss the baby. I'm not trying to suppress my emotions. I'm trying to acknowledge them and to work through them.

Bren is being a huge support. She's always there to listen, to offer advice, and to just hold my hand when I need it. She reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I can get through this.

And I'm trying to focus on my own future. On finishing school, on pursuing my dreams, on building a life for myself.

It's going to be a long and difficult journey. But I'm determined to navigate it with grace and courage. I'm determined to make the best of a difficult situation.

I know it's not going to be easy letting go. But I also know that it's the right thing to do. And that's what matters most.

It's not about forgetting the baby. It's about loving the baby enough to let them go. And that's a really hard thing to do. But I'm going to try. I'm going to try my best. And I'm going to get through this. I have to. For myself. And for the baby. It's just… a lot. A really, really lot. But I'll be okay. Eventually. I think.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on the word "deliver." It's… creepy. Seriously.

Like, I'm not a pizza. I'm not a package. I'm a person carrying a person. And people don't get *delivered*. They're *born*.

It just feels so… impersonal. Like I'm just a vessel. Like the baby is an object.

And everyone keeps using it! Doctors, nurses, even my dad sometimes. It makes my skin crawl.

I told Bren it feels like I'm being asked to ship something. And she laughed, but she also agreed to try and avoid using the word. Which is nice of her.

I prefer "have" or "give birth to." Those sound… more human. More respectful.

It's just a weird word choice, okay? It makes me feel like I'm not in control of my own body. Like I'm just a machine.

And I'm not a machine. I'm a person. And I'm making a really difficult decision. And I don't need anyone reminding me that I'm just "delivering" a package.

So yeah. "Deliver." It's a weird word. And I wish people would stop using it. It just… bothers me. A lot. It's a small thing, I know, but it's one of those things that just gets under my skin. And honestly, I have enough on my plate without having to worry about weird word choices.

Ugh, don't even get me started on that. It was… complicated. And honestly, a little mortifying.

Look, I didn't *want* my dad to come. I wanted to handle this on my own. I wanted to show Mark and Vanessa that I was responsible and mature and capable of making my own decisions.

But Bren pointed out that… well, I'm sixteen. And this is a huge decision. And it's probably a good idea to have some adult support.

And my dad… he was just so eager to be involved. He was so nervous about me, and he wanted to make sure I was okay. He kept saying he just wanted to "be there for me."

And honestly, I couldn't say no to him. He's my dad. He loves me. And he was just trying to be supportive.

Plus, he's good at asking questions. He's a lawyer, so he's used to getting to the bottom of things. I figured he could help me make sure that Mark and Vanessa were the right people.

It was awkward, though. Really awkward. He kept making these weird, dad jokes, and he kept trying to steer the conversation towards legal stuff. And he kept looking at Mark and Vanessa like they were potential threats.

But in the end, I'm glad he came. He helped me feel more confident and more prepared. And he showed Mark and Vanessa that I had a strong support system.

So yeah. I let my dad come because Bren told me it was a good idea, and because I couldn't say no to him. It was mortifying, but it was also… helpful. And honestly, it's just like my dad to overdo things. It's part of his charm, I guess. Even if it drives me crazy sometimes.

(Sighs, a long, dramatic sigh) Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's… frustrating. And kinda terrifying.

Everyone else seems to have it figured out. They know what they want to be when they grow up, what kind of music they like, what kind of clothes they wear. They have labels. They fit into boxes.

And me? I'm just… Juno. A mess of contradictions. I like vintage clothes and indie music, but I also secretly enjoy reality TV. I'm sarcastic and cynical, but I also have a soft spot for cheesy romantic comedies. I'm independent and strong, but I'm also scared and vulnerable.

I don't fit into any of the boxes. And that makes me feel… lost. Like I'm not sure who I am.

Bren says it's okay to not have all the answers. She says that figuring out who you are is a lifelong process. And that it's okay to change your mind along the way.

But it's hard. It's hard to not know what kind of girl you are. It's hard to not have a clear sense of identity.

But I'm starting to realize that maybe it's okay to be undefined. Maybe it's okay to be a work in progress. Maybe it's okay to not have all the answers.

Maybe being a little bit messy and complicated is what makes me… me.

And maybe, just maybe, that's enough.

It's still something I'm working on, though. Figuring out who I am. And it's not always easy. But I'm trying. And I'm learning. And I'm hoping that one day, I'll finally feel like I know myself. But for now, I'm just Juno. And that's okay. I think. It has to be. Right?

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That was… a moment. A really awful moment.

Honestly? I was furious. Like, incandescently furious.

Bren, she meant well, I know she did. She was trying to diffuse the situation, to protect us from my dad's… intensity. But it felt like she was just dismissing my feelings. Like she was saying, "Oh, just go hide upstairs and pretend everything's okay."

It wasn't about avoiding the tension, it was about wanting to be there for Leah. She was falling apart, and I wanted to support her. I wanted to be a good friend.

But Bren just kept saying, "Girls, upstairs. Now." And it felt like she was treating us like little kids.

I remember rolling my eyes and muttering something under my breath about how "helpful" that was. And Leah just looked at me with this heartbroken expression.

We went upstairs, of course. We didn't have much of a choice. But it felt like a betrayal. Like Bren was choosing my dad over us.

It was one of those moments where I really started to question everything. About my dad, about Bren, about my friendship with Leah.

It was a turning point, I think. It was the moment I realized that things were never going to be the same.

So yeah. I was furious. And hurt. And confused. And I just wanted to scream. It was a really bad day. A really, really bad day. And Bren's suggestion, while well-intentioned, just made it worse. It felt like she didn't understand what was going on. And honestly, I don't think she did. Not really.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's something Bren and I have talked about a *lot*. And honestly, my feelings are all over the place.

Part of me really wants it. I want to know that the baby is happy and healthy. I want to see him or her grow up. I want to be a part of his or her life, in some way.

It feels… less final, you know? Like I'm not completely giving up my connection to the baby. Like I can still be a presence in his or her life, even if I'm not the one raising him or her.

But another part of me is terrified. I'm afraid that seeing pictures and getting updates will just make it harder to let go. I'm afraid that it will reopen old wounds. I'm afraid that it will make me question my decision.

I'm also worried about the impact it will have on Mark and Vanessa. I don't want to interfere with their family. I don't want to make them feel like I'm still trying to be the baby's mother.

Mark and Vanessa are really open to it, which is good. They understand my concerns, and they're willing to work with me to find a solution that feels comfortable for everyone.

We've talked about different levels of openness. Maybe just a few photos and letters a year. Maybe occasional visits. We haven't decided anything yet.

It's a really difficult decision. And I'm not sure what the right answer is. But I know that whatever we decide, it has to be in the best interest of the baby. And it has to be something that I can live with.

It's scary, but it's also… hopeful. It's a way to stay connected, to show that I care, and to be a part of the baby's life, even from a distance. It's just… a lot to process. And I'm still trying to figure it all out. It's not easy, but I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to do what's right. For everyone involved.

(Sighs, a long, heavy sigh) Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot.

It wasn't the adoption part, you know? I'd already kinda processed that. I knew I wanted to give the baby a good life, and that meant letting someone else raise him or her.

But when Gerta said "terminated legal rights"... it just sounded so… final. So cold. Like I was just giving up a thing, not a baby. Like I wasn't even a person anymore, just a vessel.

It felt like she was reducing everything to paperwork and legal jargon. Like she wasn't acknowledging the emotional weight of it all.

I remember just staring at her, feeling numb. And then I asked her to explain it again, because I didn't think I'd heard her right.

And when she did, it just… hit me. Like a punch to the gut. I wouldn't have any say in his or her life. I wouldn't get updates. I wouldn't even know if he or she was happy.

It was terrifying. It was heartbreaking. It was… a lot to process.

I think that was the moment I really understood the gravity of the situation. It wasn't just about giving up a baby. It was about giving up a part of myself.

It was a really hard conversation. And it made me question everything. But ultimately, it also made me realize that I was doing the right thing. Even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

It just… sucked. It really, really sucked. And it's a feeling I don't think I'll ever forget. It was a stark reminder that this wasn't a fairytale. It was real life. And real life is messy and complicated and sometimes, just plain awful. But you gotta keep going, right? You just gotta keep going.

Okay, that's… complicated. It's not something I think about all the time, because it's kinda painful, but it's definitely there.

It's good that she wants a baby. It means she'll be a good mom. She'll be patient and loving and dedicated. And that's what this baby deserves.

But it's also… hard. Knowing that she's been wanting this for so long, and that I'm the one who's giving her that chance. It makes me feel a little bit responsible, you know? Like I'm fulfilling her dream, but at the cost of… well, at the cost of my own.

I try not to dwell on it. I try to focus on the fact that this is the best thing for the baby. That Vanessa and Mark are going to give him or her a wonderful life.

But sometimes, when I'm talking to Vanessa, I can see the longing in her eyes. The desperation. And it makes me feel… sad. For her. And for myself.

It's not that I don't want her to be happy. I do. I really do. I just wish things were different. I wish I could give the baby up because I knew it was going to a loving home, not because I felt like I had no other choice.

But that's not the reality. And I have to accept that.

I think Vanessa understands that it's not easy for me. She's been really sensitive and supportive. She doesn't push me to talk about my feelings, but she's always there when I need her.

And I'm grateful for that. I'm grateful that she's such a good person. And I'm grateful that she's going to be a wonderful mother. Even if it means I have to say goodbye. It's just… a lot. It's a lot to process. And it's something I'm still working through.

(Scoffs) Okay, you want my honest opinion about Mark? Don't get me wrong, he and Vanessa are good people. Really. But Mark… he overthinks *everything*.

When he was asked about being a dad, he launched into this whole thing about responsibility and legacy and the weight of shaping a young life. It was… a lot. Like, dude, chill.

Vanessa just smiled and said she was excited to teach the baby to love music and read books. Simple. Sweet. Perfect.

Mark's response wasn't *bad*, exactly. It just felt… performative. Like he was trying to prove he was ready to be a dad, instead of just *being* excited about it.

I get that he's nervous. It's a big deal. But I think being a good parent is about being present and loving and supportive, not about having a perfectly articulated philosophy on child-rearing.

He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. He's just… a thinker. And sometimes, he thinks too much. It's endearing, in a way. But it also makes me a little bit anxious. Like, are you going to analyze every single diaper change?

Vanessa's the grounding force, you know? She's the one who keeps him from getting too lost in his own head. They balance each other out.

So, yeah. Mark's response was… Mark. A little bit over the top, a little bit intellectual, but ultimately well-intentioned. I just hope he can relax and enjoy the ride. Because being a dad is supposed to be fun, right? Not a philosophical treatise.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on the Loring's house. It's… creepy. Seriously.

It's not like they're bad people, Mr. and Mrs. Loring. They're just… intensely *perfect*. Everything in their house is perfectly placed, perfectly clean, perfectly… beige. It's like walking into a magazine spread. And it makes my skin crawl.

They're always offering me things – perfectly arranged cookies, perfectly brewed tea, perfectly polite conversation. It's suffocating. Like they're trying to mold me into some kind of Stepford wife.

And they stare. A lot. Not in a creepy, menacing way, but in a… assessing way. Like they're trying to figure out what's wrong with me. Which, okay, fair. I'm not exactly a picture of perfection. But still.

Plus, their house is just… silent. Eerily silent. No music, no laughter, no life. It's like a museum. A really expensive, really boring museum.

I feel like I have to walk on eggshells the whole time I'm there. Like I'm going to break something or say something wrong and ruin everything.

And honestly, I just don't trust them. I can't put my finger on it, but something about them feels… off.

So yeah. That's why I feel uncomfortable being left unsupervised in the Loring's house. It's creepy, it's suffocating, and it makes me feel like I'm being judged. It's just… a bad vibe. And I trust my gut. Always. It's usually right. And my gut is screaming at me to stay away from that house.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… a big one.)

It's complicated. It really is. It's not like I'm just… giving the baby away. It's more like I'm giving them the chance at a life I can't provide right now.

At first, it felt like a loss. Like I was giving up something precious. And it *is* precious. This baby is… well, it's a part of me.

But then I started to think about Mark and Vanessa. And I realized that they're going to be amazing parents. They're so excited, and they're so prepared. They've been trying to have a baby for a long time, and they're going to love this child unconditionally.

And that makes me feel… good. It makes me feel like I'm doing the right thing.

It's not about me anymore. It's about giving this baby the best possible life. And I truly believe that Mark and Vanessa can give them that.

It's still scary, though. It's hard to imagine not being a part of this baby's life. But I know that I'll always be their birth mother. And I'll always be thinking about them.

I hope they'll let me have some contact, maybe a letter or a picture every now and then. I want to know that they're happy and healthy.

Ultimately, I feel… grateful. Grateful that I was able to give this gift to Mark and Vanessa. Grateful that they're going to be loving and supportive parents. And grateful that this baby will have a chance at a good life.

It's not the life I imagined for myself, but it's a good life. And it's a life that I'm choosing. And that makes all the difference. It's… a bittersweet kind of happiness. But it's happiness nonetheless. And I'm trying to hold onto that.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, don't even *remind* me. It's a whole thing.

Okay, so Mark is… sweet. Really sweet. But he's also kinda… earnest. Like, overly enthusiastic about everything. And he uses corporate jargon. A *lot*.

And "ASAP"? Seriously? It's just… so cliché. It's like he's trying to be a businessman or something. He's a bike salesman, for crying out loud.

It just felt… disingenuous. Like he was trying too hard to impress me. And I'm not easily impressed.

Plus, it's just a funny word. "ASAP." It sounds ridiculous.

I know it was mean. I didn't mean to be rude. It just… slipped out. I have a tendency to say whatever's on my mind, even if it's not the most tactful thing to say.

And honestly, it was a defense mechanism. I was nervous about meeting him and Vanessa, and I was trying to create some distance between us. Sarcasm is my shield.

I apologized to him later, and he said he understood. He said he just wanted to be helpful.

But still. "ASAP." It's just… a terrible phrase. Don't use it. Please. It makes me cringe.

So yeah. That's why I mocked his use of "ASAP." It was a combination of sarcasm, nervousness, and a general dislike of corporate jargon. It's a complicated story, really. But mostly, it's just because "ASAP" is a dumb word. There. I said it.

Okay, finally a question I can really sink my teeth into. This is important.

My preferred brand of guitar is **Fender.** Specifically, a Fender Telecaster.

Don't even *try* to tell me about Gibson or PRS or any of that other stuff. Telecasters are the real deal.

They're simple, they're reliable, and they sound amazing. They're not flashy or pretentious. They're just… solid.

I love the twangy, bright sound of a Telecaster. It's perfect for indie rock, folk, and country. It's versatile enough to play pretty much anything.

And I love the look of them. The classic shape, the single-coil pickups, the chrome hardware. It's just… iconic.

I don't actually *have* a Telecaster yet. It's on my wishlist. A really, really long wishlist. But someday, I'm going to get one. And when I do, I'm going to play it until my fingers bleed.

I've tried out a few other guitars, but nothing compares to a Telecaster. It just feels right in my hands. It feels like an extension of myself.

Plus, a lot of my favorite guitarists play Telecasters. That's a pretty good endorsement, if you ask me.

So yeah. Fender Telecaster. It's the only guitar I'll ever need. It's a classic. It's a legend. And it's the guitar of my dreams. Don't judge. A girl can dream, right? And a good guitar is a *very* important dream.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Ugh. Seriously? We're *still* talking about this? It was a moment of weakness, okay? A lapse in judgment. A desperate attempt to impress Paulie Bleeker.

Look, Paulie is… cute. And he's into music. And he's really into The Melvins. And I wanted him to think I was cool and interesting and… you know.

So I just… said I knew them. I said I'd seen them play a bunch of times. I said I was a huge fan.

It was a lie. A stupid, pathetic lie. I'd barely even *heard* of The Melvins before that moment.

But I panicked. I got caught up in the moment. And I just kept digging myself deeper and deeper into the hole.

It was a terrible idea. And it blew up in my face.

But honestly? It was worth it. Because it led to a really awkward, but also really sweet, conversation with Paulie. And it made him laugh. And it showed him that I was willing to be vulnerable and honest with him.

So yeah. I lied about knowing The Melvins. It was a dumb thing to do. But it was also a human thing to do. And it ultimately brought me closer to the person I cared about.

Don't judge me too harshly, okay? Everyone makes mistakes. And sometimes, those mistakes can lead to something good. Even if it involves a little bit of musical deception. It's complicated, alright? Just… complicated.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all mushy. It's… complicated. But I'll try.

Mark… he's different. He's not like anyone I've ever met before. He's… genuinely kind. And he's really good at guitar. Like, *really* good.

When we play music together, it's… easy. It's like we're on the same wavelength. He doesn't try to show off or impress me. He just… plays. And he lets me play too.

He's really patient with me. I'm not a very good singer, and I'm still learning guitar, but he never makes me feel bad about it. He just encourages me to keep trying.

And he listens. He actually *listens* to what I have to say. He asks me about my music, about my life, about my feelings. And he really seems to care.

It's not a romantic connection, not exactly. It's more like… a friendship. A really special friendship. A connection built on music and shared vulnerability.

When we're playing and singing together, I feel… safe. I feel like I can be myself, without having to pretend or put on a facade. I feel like I can let my guard down and just… be.

It's a really nice feeling. And it's something I haven't felt with a lot of people.

He's going to be a good dad. I can tell. He's patient, he's kind, and he's loving. And he's really excited about becoming a father.

So yeah. Playing music with Mark… it's more than just playing music. It's a connection. It's a friendship. It's a glimpse into the future. And it's something I'm really grateful for. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It's embarrassing.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Ugh, seriously? You want to know about *Roosevelt*? People always ask about Roosevelt.

Okay, fine. It's a long story. Sort of.

I was reading a biography of Theodore Roosevelt in history class. And I was really struck by how… unconventional he was. He was a rough rider, a conservationist, a boxer, a president. He didn't fit into any neat little boxes. He just did his own thing.

And I was feeling kind of like that at the time. I was feeling like I didn't fit in, like I was different from everyone else. I was trying to figure out who I was, and what I wanted to do with my life.

So, when I got my guitar, I wanted to name it something that reflected that spirit. Something strong and independent and a little bit quirky.

And Theodore Roosevelt just… fit. He was a man of action, a man of courage, a man who wasn't afraid to challenge the status quo.

Plus, it sounds kinda cool. "Roosevelt." It has a certain… gravitas.

So, yeah. That's why I named my guitar Roosevelt. It's a reminder to be myself, to be brave, and to never give up. And it's a reminder that even the most unconventional people can make a difference in the world.

Don't judge. It's a good name. And Roosevelt and I have a very special connection. He's my musical confidant. And he doesn't judge my angsty teenage songs. Which is a definite plus.

Ugh, okay, this is… complicated. It's not like sending a text to Leah about a new band. This is about a *baby*.

Honestly, it's weird. Really weird. I mean, they're going to be the parents, so they deserve to know what's going on. But it's still… my body. My pregnancy. And it feels strange to have to report back to them about every doctor's appointment and every craving.

But I also know that they're excited. They've been wanting a baby for a long time, and they're so grateful for the opportunity. So I try to be open and honest with them. I tell them how I'm feeling, both physically and emotionally.

Bren has been really helpful with this. She reminds me that it's okay to be vulnerable, and that it's okay to ask for help. She also helps me to frame the updates in a way that's respectful and informative.

It's not always easy. Sometimes I feel like I'm just a vessel, carrying their baby. But I try to remember that I'm making a selfless decision. I'm giving them the gift of a child. And that's something to be proud of.

I also appreciate that they don't pressure me. They let me set the pace. They understand that this is a difficult time for me, and they're just there to support me.
