When Bren first found out about Mark, she didn't yell or get angry. She just… looked heartbroken. And really, really worried. She sat me down and just… talked to me. Like a grown-up. Which, honestly, was more terrifying than if she *had* yelled.

I tried to brush it off at first. I told her it wasn't what it looked like. That we were just friends. That he was just being supportive. Which was a total lie.

But Bren isn't stupid. She saw right through me. She asked me if I was happy. If I was being treated with respect. If I was thinking about the consequences.

And I couldn't answer. Because I knew she was right. It was a bad situation. A really bad situation.

I got defensive, of course. I told her she didn't understand. That it was complicated. That I had feelings for him.

But she didn't back down. She just kept asking questions. And she kept reminding me that I deserved better.

Finally, I broke down and admitted everything. I told her how lonely I was, how confused I was, and how I had made a terrible mistake.

She didn't say "I told you so." She just held me and told me that it was going to be okay. And that we would figure it out together.

She made me realize that Mark wasn't a solution to my problems. He *was* the problem. And that I needed to focus on myself and on the baby.

It was a really hard conversation. But it was also a turning point. It was the moment I realized that I needed to end things with Mark. And that Bren was right. I deserved better.

So, I told Mark it was over. It was awful. He tried to convince me to stay, but I stood my ground. And Bren was there for me every step of the way.

It was a painful experience, but it taught me a valuable lesson. About boundaries, about self-respect, and about the importance of having someone who cares about you enough to tell you the truth, even when it's hard to hear. And Bren? She's the best at that. Seriously. Don't even get me started on how amazing she is.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling my eyes) Oh. *That*. Everyone always asks about the slushie.

Look, it was a complicated day, okay? Mr. Mundy was being… Mr. Mundy. All preachy and judgmental and just generally annoying. He was going on and on about respect and grief and how you're supposed to *act* at a funeral.

And honestly, it just felt… wrong. Like he was trying to control everything, even people's emotions. And I was just… frustrated. And I had a blue raspberry slushie.

It wasn't about disrespecting the deceased, okay? It was about rebelling against Mr. Mundy's ridiculous expectations. It was about saying, "I'm not going to pretend to be sad just because you want me to be."

It was a stupid thing to do, I admit. But it felt good in the moment. It felt like a small act of defiance.

And honestly, it was kind of funny. The look on Mr. Mundy's face was priceless.

So yeah. I poured my blue slushie into the urn. It was a moment of teenage rebellion. And it's a story I'll probably be telling for the rest of my life. Don't judge. You had to be there. It was a whole *thing*. And honestly, sometimes you just need to pour a blue slushie into an urn. It's therapeutic. Okay? Don't look at me like that.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Growing up is hard enough *without* adding a whole pregnancy into the mix.

Honestly, it was a lot of flailing and trying not to fall apart. A lot of tears. A lot of sarcasm. And a lot of leaning on the people who cared about me.

Bren was a lifesaver. She didn't judge me, she just listened. She helped me navigate the medical stuff, the emotional stuff, the practical stuff. She was just… there. Always.

My dad was… well, my dad. He was worried, obviously. But he was also supportive. He just wanted me to be okay.

And even Leah, even though things were complicated between us, she eventually came around. She helped me pick out baby names, and she even came with me to a few doctor's appointments.

I also started journaling. It helped me to process my feelings and to make sense of everything that was happening. It was a way to get my thoughts out of my head and onto paper.

And I listened to a lot of music. Music always makes things better.

But the biggest thing that helped me cope was accepting that I wasn't alone. There were other people who had been through similar situations. And there were people who cared about me and wanted to help.

It was also about learning to be kind to myself. To forgive myself for my mistakes. And to remember that I was still a person, even though I was pregnant.

It was a really challenging time, but it also made me stronger. It forced me to grow up faster than I was ready to. But it also taught me a lot about myself, about life, and about the importance of love and support.

It wasn't easy, but I got through it. And I'm proud of myself for that. It wasn't the path I expected, but it was the path I was on. And I learned to navigate it, one day at a time. And honestly, that's all anyone can do. Just keep moving forward, even when it's hard.

Ugh, okay. Talking about Mark is… complicated. It's not that he's *bad*, it's just… weird. He's a grown-up. And I'm, you know, a teenager who's currently housing another human being. It's a strange dynamic.

The first few times, it was super awkward. Like, intensely awkward. I kept accidentally calling him "sir" and tripping over my words. He tried to be cool and casual, but you could tell he was nervous too.

He's… really earnest. Like, *really* earnest. He asks a lot of questions. About my life, about my interests, about what I want for the baby. It's not intrusive, exactly, but it's a lot.

He tried to bond with me over music, which was sweet, but he mostly just played really boring dad rock. No offense to dad rock, but it's not exactly my vibe. I tried to introduce him to The Moldy Peaches, but he didn't really get it. He said it sounded "sad."

But he's also… kind. Genuinely kind. He and Vanessa are really excited about having a baby, and they seem like they would be good parents. They're patient and understanding, and they're willing to listen.

He made me hot chocolate one time, and it was actually really good. And he brought me a book, a collection of poems by Mary Oliver. Which was a nice gesture.

It's still weird, though. It's hard to imagine handing over my baby to someone I barely know. But Mark and Vanessa are trying. They're trying to get to know me, to build a relationship with me. And I'm trying to be open to it.

It's not easy. But I think… I think they're good people. And I think they would give the baby a good life. And that's all I can really ask for, right? It's just… a lot to process. And it's definitely not how I pictured my junior year going. But hey, life's full of surprises, right? Mostly unpleasant ones, in my experience.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… mortifying.

Okay, so, there I was, trying to have a semi-normal conversation with Bleeker, right? Trying to act cool and casual, like I wasn't carrying a human being inside me. And he just… blurted it out.

"Wow, you're really… showing."

Like, thanks, Bleeker. I hadn't noticed. It's not like I'm trying to hide it or anything.

It wasn't even the comment itself that was so bad. It was the way he said it. Like I was some kind of science experiment. Like he was surprised that my body was actually doing what it's supposed to do.

And then he tried to backtrack, saying something about how "it's cool" and "you're glowing." But it just made it worse.

I just wanted to disappear. I wanted the ground to swallow me whole. I wanted to yell at him for being so insensitive.

But I didn't. I just mumbled something about being comfortable and changed the subject.

It was just… awkward. And embarrassing. And it reminded me that everyone was staring at me, judging me, and talking about me.

It was a really vulnerable moment, and he just completely missed it.

Honestly, I was mostly just annoyed. Like, thanks for pointing out the obvious, Bleeker. I'm pregnant. It's kind of hard to miss.

It just… reinforced the fact that this whole situation is weird and uncomfortable and that people don't always know what to say.

So yeah. That was not a fun moment. And I'm still slightly bitter about it. Bleeker. Honestly. Some people.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me cry. Seriously.

The most challenging part… it wasn't the appointments, or the paperwork, or even the physical stuff. It was the… letting go.

It sounds cliché, I know. But it's true.

I knew from the beginning that I wanted to give the baby up for adoption. It was the right decision. The best decision. But knowing that and *feeling* that are two completely different things.

As the pregnancy progressed, I started to feel more and more connected to the baby. I started to imagine what he or she would be like. I started to dream about the future.

And then I realized that I was going to have to say goodbye. That I was going to have to give up my chance to be a mother.

And that was… devastating.

It was like a part of me was being ripped away. It was like losing a piece of my heart.

I spent a lot of nights crying myself to sleep. I spent a lot of time questioning my decision. I spent a lot of time wondering if I was doing the right thing.

But I knew that I was. I knew that giving the baby up for adoption was the best thing for him or her. It was the best thing for me.

But that didn't make it any easier.

The actual day I handed the baby over to Mark and Vanessa was the hardest day of my life. It was like saying goodbye to a piece of myself.

And even now, months later, I still think about the baby. I wonder how he or she is doing. I wonder if he or she is happy.

It's a pain that I know I'll carry with me for a long time. But it's a pain that I also know is worth it. Because I know that the baby is in good hands. And I know that I made the right decision.

So yeah. Letting go. That was the most challenging part. And it's something I'll never forget. It's a wound that will probably always be there, but it's a wound that reminds me of my strength, my courage, and my love. And that's something I can be proud of. Even if it hurts like hell.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was… a lot.

He was standing out there with a sign, all red-faced and yelling. And he kept shouting about how babies are "miracles" and "gifts from God" and how I was "throwing away a precious life."

It was… infuriating. And honestly, really insensitive. Like he had no idea what I was going through.

He kept saying things like, "That baby has a heartbeat! It's a human being!" And, "You're committing murder!"

It was just… so black and white. So judgmental. He didn't see the complexities of the situation. He didn't see the fact that I was making a difficult decision for the good of everyone involved.

He didn't see that I was trying to give that baby a chance at a good life, even if it wasn't with me.

He just saw a "sin."

Honestly, it made me even more sure that I was doing the right thing. Because if that's what being pro-life means – shaming and judging people – then I want no part of it.

It was a really awful experience. And it's something I'll never forget. It just… reinforced how complicated everything was. And how important it was to make a decision that was right for *me*. And for the baby. Even if it meant facing the judgment of strangers. Ugh. Just thinking about him makes my blood boil. He was the worst.

(Sighs, looks down for a moment) Okay. This is… not a fun memory. But you asked.

I went to the clinic with Leah. She was supposed to be support, which she was, mostly. But it was still… awful. It smelled like antiseptic and sadness.

There was a woman there, sitting in the waiting room. Older, maybe in her fifties. She was knitting. A really complicated-looking scarf. She kept glancing at me, and I tried to avoid eye contact. I was already feeling like everyone was judging me.

Finally, she looked right at me and… she didn't say anything judgmental. She didn't preach or lecture or offer unwanted advice.

She just said, “You’re braver than you think you are.”

That was it. Just those six words.

It sounds so simple, but it hit me really hard. Because at that moment, I didn’t feel brave at all. I felt scared and confused and completely overwhelmed.

But she saw something in me that I didn’t see in myself. She saw my strength. She saw my courage.

She didn’t ask me why I was there. She didn’t ask me about my situation. She just offered me a kind word.

And it made all the difference.

I never saw her again. I don’t know who she was. But I’ll never forget what she said.

It’s a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is still kindness in the world. And that even when you feel like you’re all alone, there are people who believe in you.

It’s a small moment, but it’s a moment that changed me. It gave me the strength to keep going. And it reminded me that I was capable of more than I thought I was.

So yeah. That woman. She said, “You’re braver than you think you are.” And she was right. I was. And I still am. Even now.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… a moment.

Okay, so Su-Chin, she's… intense. Very into labels and diagnoses and categorizing everything. And I just casually mentioned I thought maybe Paul might have ADHD and that's why he was so hyper. And I, like, offhandedly said something about Adderall.

Her face. Oh. My. God.

It was like I'd confessed to robbing a bank. She went *completely* silent for a second, then started lecturing me about the dangers of self-diagnosing and the importance of professional medical advice. She was all, "Adderall is a serious medication! It's not something to just throw around!"

It was so awkward. I just wanted to talk about Paul being weird, not have a full-blown intervention about pharmaceutical drugs.

She kept going on and on about how irresponsible it was of me to even *suggest* it. And she kept looking at me like I was some kind of drug dealer.

I tried to explain that I wasn't advocating for anyone to take medication, I was just trying to understand why Paul was acting so… Paul. But she wasn't having it.

It was a really uncomfortable conversation. And it definitely made me realize that Su-Chin takes things *very* seriously. Like, way too seriously.

Honestly, it was one of the reasons I started avoiding her a little bit. She just brings a lot of… intensity to everything. And sometimes, you just need someone who can laugh things off, you know? Not someone who's going to give you a lecture about the dangers of Adderall.

So yeah. Su-Chin did *not* react well. It was a disaster. A complete and utter disaster. And I'm still cringing about it.

Ugh, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It was… a lot.

Okay, so, the waiting room. It smelled like antiseptic and regret. And everyone in there was trying really hard *not* to make eye contact. Which, honestly, just made it worse.

But it wasn't the smell, or the awkward silence, or even the other people that terrified me. It was the magazines.

Seriously. The magazines.

They were all baby magazines. Like, "What to Expect When You're Expecting" and "Choosing the Perfect Name" and "Nursery Decorating Ideas."

And every single one of them was filled with pictures of happy, glowing couples, cradling their perfect little babies.

And it just… hit me. Like a ton of bricks.

I wasn't a happy, glowing couple. I was a sixteen-year-old girl who was giving her baby up for adoption. And I wasn't choosing a nursery theme, I was trying to figure out how to say goodbye.

It felt like everyone in that waiting room was judging me. Like they knew my story, and they were silently disapproving.

And it made me feel so alone. So scared. So… lost.

I just wanted to disappear. To crawl under a rock and never come out.

I kept flipping through the magazines, trying to find something, *anything*, that reflected my situation. But there was nothing. It was all just… perfect families and happy endings.

And it just made me feel even more terrified. Because I knew my story wasn't going to have a happy ending. At least, not in the traditional sense.

So yeah. The magazines. That's what caught my attention and made me feel terrified in the waiting room. It was a stark reminder of everything I was losing. And everything I was giving up. It was awful. Just… awful.

(Sighs dramatically and rolls eyes) Ugh. Seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been… a while.

Okay, fine. Yes. I… still think about him sometimes. Don't get me wrong, it's not like I'm pining away or anything. I'm not writing him love letters or anything ridiculous.

But he was… sweet. And funny. And he actually *listened* to me. Which is more than I can say for a lot of people.

And he was genuinely excited about my poetry, which was… nice. It's not every day someone appreciates my angsty teenage ramblings.

But things are complicated now. Obviously. I have a lot on my plate. And he has his music. And we're just… in different places.

I think I realized that we were more like good friends than… anything else. We had a connection, but it wasn't a romantic connection.

I still care about him, though. I want him to be happy. I just… don't see a future for us.

It's hard to explain. It's just… complicated.

So yeah. I still have feelings for him, in a way. But they're not the kind of feelings that are going to lead to a happily ever after. They're just… feelings. And I'm trying to accept that.

Can we please talk about something else now? This is getting awkward. Seriously. I need a distraction. Maybe we can talk about vintage clothes? Or indie music? Anything but Bleeker. Please.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Okay, don't even get me started. Vanessa is… enthusiastic. About decorating.

It's not *bad*, per se. It's just… a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

She's gone full-on pastel everything. Pink and blue and yellow. It looks like a unicorn exploded in there. And there are little animal figurines *everywhere*. Like, a whole menagerie.

She keeps asking me what I think, and I try to be polite. I say things like, "It's very… cheerful," and "The color scheme is… interesting." Which is code for "It's overwhelming."

Mark is trying to reign her in, but he's outnumbered. He keeps suggesting a more neutral palette, but Vanessa is adamant about creating a "whimsical and enchanting" space for the baby.

Honestly, I'm a little worried the baby is going to be overstimulated before they're even born. It's like a sensory overload waiting to happen.

I suggested maybe toning it down a little, adding some vintage touches, but she just smiled and said, "Oh, honey, vintage is lovely, but this is a *baby's* room! It needs to be bright and happy!"

Look, I appreciate that she's excited. And I know she wants to create a beautiful space for the baby. But sometimes, less is more.

I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a lifelong aversion to pastel colors. And that they don't get nightmares about the army of animal figurines.

It's going to be… an experience. That's for sure. A very, very colorful experience. And I'm just bracing myself for it. It's Vanessa's thing, and I'm trying to be supportive. Even if it means living with a room that looks like a Lisa Frank fever dream.

(Scoffs) Nesting? Oh, please. That's… complicated.

Look, I'm giving this baby up for adoption. It's not like I'm planning on keeping it. So the whole idea of decorating a nursery and buying tiny clothes and… ugh. It feels weird.

It feels like I'm pretending. Like I'm getting attached. And I can't afford to get attached. It'll just make things harder.

Mark and Vanessa are taking care of all that stuff. They're the ones who are going to be raising the baby. They're the ones who should be picking out the paint color and the crib and the little stuffed animals.

I've offered to help, but they said they want to do it themselves. And honestly, I'm relieved.

I don't want to create a perfect little world for a baby that I'm not going to be able to stay in. It would just be too painful.

I'm focusing on other things. On finishing school. On taking care of myself. On preparing for the future.

I'm happy for Mark and Vanessa. I want them to have everything they need to welcome their baby into the world. But I need to keep my distance. I need to protect myself.

It's not that I don't care. It's just that I can't get involved. It's too much.

So, yeah. Nesting? Not my thing. I'm good. I'll leave that to the people who are actually going to be raising the baby. It's the only way I can cope. It's the only way I can move forward. It's… complicated. Okay? It's just really, really complicated.

Ugh, don't even get me started on those people. Seriously. It was… a whole other planet.

It was like watching a different species. All perfectly coiffed hair and designer handbags and… just *stuff*. So much stuff.

They didn't even seem to *want* most of it. They were just… buying it. Like it was some kind of competition. Like their worth was measured by how much money they spent.

And the sales associates? They were practically worshiping them. "Oh, Ms. So-and-So, that color looks *divine* on you!" "Allow me to find you the matching shoes!" It was nauseating.

It just felt so… empty. Like they were trying to fill a void with material possessions. And it wasn't working.

I mean, I like a good vintage find as much as the next person, but there's a difference between appreciating something and just… consuming it.

It made me feel really uncomfortable, honestly. Like I didn't belong there. Like I was an outsider looking in.

And it made me think about all the people who don't have enough. All the people who are struggling to make ends meet. And it just felt… wrong.

It's not that I'm against people spending their money on things they enjoy. But it's just… the whole spectacle of it. The excess. The superficiality. It's just… a lot.

It's a weird world, you know? And sometimes, it's just really hard to make sense of it. Those women at the mall? They just reinforced that feeling. It was like a glimpse into a reality I don't understand, and frankly, don't want to be a part of. It was… unsettling. Really unsettling.

(Sighs, a long, complicated sigh) Okay, that's… a lot. It's not like I haven't been thinking about it, but actually *talking* about it is different.

Look, I'm not going to pretend I'm thrilled about giving up a baby. It sucks. It really, really sucks. It's probably the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

But I also know that I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being.

And that's why I chose adoption. Because I want this baby to have the best possible life. A life that I can't provide right now.

But that doesn't mean I'm not thinking about the changes and the responsibilities. It means I'm trying to be realistic.

I know I'll always have a connection to this baby. I'll always wonder what their life is like. And I'll always feel a sense of loss.

But I also know that I can be a supportive presence in their life, even from a distance. I can send them letters, or pictures, or gifts. I can be a friend.

And I know that I have a responsibility to make sure they know they were loved and wanted.

It's scary, honestly. It's a huge responsibility. And I'm not sure I'm up to it.

But I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to focus on the positive. And I'm trying to trust that everything will work out the way it's supposed to.

It's not the life I imagined for myself. But it's my life. And I'm going to make the best of it. Even if it's hard. Even if it hurts.

Because that's what you do, right? You face your challenges head-on. You learn from your mistakes. And you keep moving forward. Even when you're scared. Especially when you're scared.

So yeah. The changes and responsibilities are daunting. But I'm ready to face them. I have to be. For the baby. And for myself. It's not going to be easy, but I'm going to do it. I have to.

Okay, you're getting into the really hard stuff now. It's not like I just randomly picked Mark and Vanessa out of a catalog. It's… complicated.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because honestly, who *is* perfect? It was about finding people who I felt could give the baby something I couldn't.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out my own life. I'm not financially stable. I'm not emotionally ready to be a mom. And I don't want to bring a child into the world and not be able to give them everything they need.

But it wasn't just about what *I* couldn't provide. It was about what Mark and Vanessa *could* provide.

They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're older, they're settled, they have a beautiful home and a stable life. They're financially secure. They're just… ready.

And they're not looking for a perfect baby. They're looking for a baby to love. They're looking for a child to raise. They're looking for a family.

I met them through the agency, and we talked a lot. They asked me questions about my life, about my hopes and dreams for the baby. And I asked them questions about their life, about their values, about their plans for the future.

And I just… felt a connection with them. They seemed kind and compassionate and genuine. They seemed like people who would love the baby unconditionally.

It wasn't about finding parents who were better than me. It was about finding parents who could give the baby a better life than I could. And that's what mattered most.

It's still hard, don't get me wrong. It's the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But I know, deep down, that it's the right one. For everyone involved. And that's what keeps me going. It's knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for, and that they'll have a chance to thrive. And that's all I can ask for.

Ugh. Okay, let's be real. If I decided to keep the baby… it wouldn't be a walk in the park. It would be… a monumental mess.

First, there's school. I'd have to figure out how to finish my education while also taking care of a baby. That would be incredibly difficult. I'd probably have to drop out, or go to night school, or something. It would definitely derail my plans for the future.

Then there's the financial aspect. I don't have any money. My dad and Bren are supportive, but they're not exactly wealthy. I'd have to rely on government assistance, or find a way to get a job. And even then, it would be a struggle to make ends meet.

And then there's the emotional toll. Being a single mom at sixteen would be incredibly challenging. I'm not ready for that kind of responsibility. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone raising a child.

I'd also have to deal with the judgment of others. People would probably look down on me, or criticize my choices. And that would be really hard to handle.

And honestly, I'm not sure I'm capable of giving a child everything they need. I want my baby to have a good life, and I'm not sure I can provide that.

It's not that I don't love the baby. I do. But I also have to be realistic. I have to think about what's best for the baby, and for myself.

And right now, I don't think keeping the baby is the best option. It would be a struggle for both of us. And I want the baby to have a loving and stable home, with parents who are ready and able to provide for them.

So yeah. School, finances, emotional toll, judgment, and the ability to provide a good life. Those are the obstacles I'd face if I decided to keep the baby. And they're pretty significant. It's not a decision I take lightly. It's a really hard decision. And that's why I've chosen adoption. It's the best option for everyone involved. Even if it breaks my heart a little bit.

Ugh, don't remind me. It was… a lot.

Leah, bless her heart, she was *not* happy about the adoption plan. She thought I was making a huge mistake. She kept saying I was being selfish, and that I'd regret it for the rest of my life.

She suggested… well, she suggested I just keep the baby and raise it with her.

Yeah. You heard that right. She wanted us to raise a baby *together*.

She had this whole plan worked out. She'd finish high school, get a job, and we'd share the responsibilities. She even started picking out names.

It was… overwhelming. And honestly, a little bit terrifying.

I mean, Leah is a great friend, but we're sixteen! We're barely capable of taking care of ourselves, let alone a baby.

I tried to explain to her that it wasn't realistic. That I wasn't ready to be a mom. That I had my own life to live.

But she wouldn't listen. She was convinced that we could make it work.

It caused a huge fight between us. We didn't talk for weeks. It was really painful.

Eventually, she came around and realized that I was doing what was best for everyone. But it took a long time. And it definitely strained our friendship.

It was a really difficult time. And it's a conversation I'd rather not revisit, honestly. But yeah. Leah wanted us to raise the baby together. It was… a lot to process. A *lot*.

(Sighs heavily, looking down) Okay, you're bringing up the play area. Ugh. That was… not my finest moment.

Look, it was stupid. It was mean. And I'm not proud of it.

I was… insecure, okay? I was feeling really awkward and out of place. I was pregnant, and everyone else seemed to have their lives together. They were all happy moms, pushing their kids on swings and chatting about baby stuff. And I just… I felt like I didn't belong.

So I made a joke. A really dumb, insensitive joke about their leggings and their minivan conversations. It was a way to deflect my own feelings of inadequacy. It was a way to feel superior, even though I wasn't.

It was wrong. I know that now. I hurt their feelings, and I made myself look like a jerk.

I apologized to Leah afterward, and she was really mad at me. She told me that it wasn't okay to make fun of people just because I was feeling insecure. And she was right.

I've been trying to be more mindful of my words and actions ever since. I've been trying to be more empathetic and understanding.

It was a learning experience, I guess. A painful one. But it taught me that it's never okay to put others down to make myself feel better.

So yeah. I made fun of the women at the play area. And I regret it. It was a stupid, mean thing to do. And I'm trying to be better. I really am. It just… slipped out. I was being a defensive, insecure teenager. And I'm sorry. Truly.

(Scoffs) Okay, wow. That's… direct. And honestly, a little bit personal. But alright, I'll answer it.

It wasn't like I *allowed* her, exactly. It just… happened. It wasn't a planned thing.

We were at an appointment, and she was talking about how excited she was to be a mom. And she just… reached out and touched my belly.

And it was weird. Really weird. I mean, it's my body, and this baby is… was… inside me. It felt strange to have someone else touch it.

But it also felt… okay.

Vanessa is a really kind person. And she was so gentle. And she was so excited. And I could see how much she wanted this baby.

And I realized that she wasn't just touching my belly. She was touching her future. She was touching her dreams.

It was a way for her to connect with the baby. And it was a way for me to connect with her.

It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot. It reminded me that I wasn't alone in this. And it reminded me that I was doing the right thing.

It was still awkward, don't get me wrong. But it was also… beautiful. In a weird, complicated way.

So yeah. That's why I let Vanessa touch my belly. It wasn't about me. It was about her. And about the baby. And about making the best decision for everyone involved. It was about letting go, and trusting that this baby was going to be loved and cared for. And honestly, it was a little bit of a relief. It was a step closer to… everything being okay.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh, don't even *get* me started on the "belly bump shuffle." It's the most awkward thing *ever*.

It's like, suddenly, people feel the need to treat me like I'm made of glass. They practically part the Red Sea when I walk by. They hold doors open for me, they offer me their seats on the bus, they give me these… pitying looks.

It's not that I'm ungrateful, okay? It's just… weird. I'm still me. I'm still Juno. I'm still sarcastic and independent and capable of walking without falling over.

I think it's because they see the bump and they immediately assume I'm helpless. They see a pregnant girl and they think, "Oh, she must be fragile and delicate."

Which is ridiculous. I'm not fragile. I'm actually pretty tough. I've been through a lot lately, and I'm still standing.

But people don't see that. They just see the bump. And they react accordingly.

It's like I've been transformed into some kind of maternal icon. A symbol of vulnerability and innocence.

It's… unsettling.

I wish people would just treat me like a normal person. Like a teenager. Like Juno.

But I guess that's not going to happen. Not until this bump goes away.

So I just try to ignore it. I try to walk with my head held high and pretend that I don't notice the stares and the awkward shuffling.

But it's hard. It's really hard. It's just another reminder that my life has changed. And that I'm not the same person I used to be.

Ugh. It's just… frustrating. Can people just, like, *not* treat me differently? Is that too much to ask?

(Sighs, runs a hand through my hair) Okay, this is… complicated. Everyone keeps saying how *perfect* Mark and Vanessa are. "Such a lovely couple," "They're going to be wonderful parents," blah blah blah. And they *are* nice. Really nice.

But that's kind of the problem. They're… *too* perfect.

It's not that I don't think they'll be good parents. I do. They'll give the baby a stable home, a good education, and a lot of love. But they have this… curated life. Everything is so neat and tidy and planned out. Their house is spotless, their clothes are always matching, and they talk about college funds and organic baby food.

And it just feels… sterile.

My life is messy. My family is messy. We're not perfect, and we don't pretend to be. We have flaws and quirks and we make mistakes. And I want the baby to be loved for who they are, flaws and all.

I worry that Mark and Vanessa will try to mold the baby into something they want them to be, instead of letting them be themselves. I worry that they'll be disappointed if the baby doesn't fit their perfect little picture.

It's not that I don't trust them. It's just that I'm scared. Scared that the baby will lose a part of themselves in the process. Scared that they won't be allowed to be messy and imperfect and real.

I know it sounds irrational. I know I'm probably overthinking things. But it's a big decision, and I want to make sure I'm doing what's best for the baby. And sometimes, what's best isn't always what's easiest or what looks the most perfect on the outside. It's about finding a family that will love the baby unconditionally, for exactly who they are. And that's what I'm looking for. It's just… harder than I thought it would be.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's not like talking about a band or a movie. This is real life.

But I'll be honest. At first, I was really, really scared to meet them. I mean, I was handing over my baby. It was a huge deal. And I didn't know what to expect.

I was worried they'd be judgmental, or weird, or… I don't know. Just not good people.

But they weren't like that at all. They were… kind. And gentle. And genuinely excited.

They didn't try to interrogate me, or to make me feel guilty. They just listened. They asked me how *I* was feeling. And they told me they were grateful.

They're… normal. In a good way. They're not rich or famous or anything. They're just a regular couple who want to be parents.

They have a really nice house, and a dog named Winston. And they've already started preparing the nursery. It's… weird to think about, but it's also kind of nice.

I still have moments where I feel sad, or scared, or uncertain. But I also feel… relieved. And hopeful.

I think they're going to be really good parents. They're loving and patient and responsible. And they're going to give the baby a life that I can't give him or her.

It's not easy, letting go. But knowing that the baby is going to be with Mark and Vanessa… it makes it a little bit easier.

So yeah. I like them. I really do. They're good people. And I trust them with my baby. And that's all that matters. It's still hard, but… they make it a little less hard. And I'm grateful for that. Really grateful.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Mrs. Bleeker. That woman is… intense.

Okay, so, she doesn't approve of me for a bunch of reasons, but mostly because she thinks I'm a bad influence on her precious Bleeker. She thinks I'm too… cynical. Too sarcastic. Too independent. Basically, too *me*.

She's got this whole vision for Bleeker's future, you know? He's supposed to go to Brown, become a doctor, marry a nice girl from a good family, and live a perfectly respectable life. And I definitely don't fit into that picture.

She thinks I'm going to distract him from his studies. She thinks I'm going to lead him astray. She thinks I'm going to ruin his life.

It's ridiculous, honestly. Bleeker is a smart guy. He can make his own decisions. He doesn't need his mom to tell him what to do.

But Mrs. Bleeker is very… persuasive. And she's not afraid to use guilt trips and passive-aggressive comments to get her way.

She's also really judgmental. She doesn't understand my sense of humor, and she doesn't approve of my vintage clothes. She thinks I'm too "alternative."

Honestly, I think she's just scared. She's scared of change, and she's scared of anything that threatens her control over Bleeker.

It's a complicated situation. I like Bleeker, but I'm not sure I can deal with his mom forever. She's exhausting. And frankly, she's a little bit terrifying.

So yeah. That's why Mrs. Bleeker doesn't approve of me. Because I'm not the daughter she wants for her son. And honestly, I'm okay with that. I'm not trying to be anyone's ideal daughter. I'm just trying to be myself. And if that's not good enough for her, then that's her problem.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's… complicated.

Honestly? I was being stubborn. Really stubborn.

After I told Mark and Vanessa I was choosing them, things were… awkward. I was trying to be polite, but I was also keeping my distance. I was scared of getting too attached, of letting myself feel too much.

Mark, he's a good guy. Really good. He's quiet and thoughtful, and he just… gets it. He knew I was struggling, and he wanted to do something to help.

So he made me a CD. A mix of songs that he thought I'd like. It was a really sweet gesture, but I just… left it on the counter for days. I didn't want to listen to it. I didn't want to let myself feel anything.

Bren noticed, of course. She always notices everything. She gently nudged me, told me to give it a chance. She said it was a way for Mark to connect with me, to show me he cared.

But I still resisted. I was afraid that if I listened to the CD, I'd start to feel too much. That I'd start to see Mark and Vanessa as… parents. And that would make everything even harder.

But then, one night, I was feeling particularly lonely and overwhelmed. I was just sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, and I couldn't sleep.

And I just… reached for the CD.

I put it in my Discman (yeah, I still have a Discman, don't judge), and I pressed play.

And the first song that came on was… Belle & Sebastian. "The Boy with the Arab Strap."

And it just… clicked.

It was like Mark had reached into my brain and pulled out all my favorite songs. He understood me. He understood my taste in music. He understood… me.

And in that moment, I realized that he wasn't just a stranger. He was someone who cared about me. Someone who wanted to be a part of my life.

And it made me feel… less alone.

So yeah. I started listening to the CD because I was lonely and stubborn and scared. But I kept listening because it made me feel connected. It made me feel understood. And it made me feel… hopeful. It was a small thing, but it made a big difference. It was a turning point. And I'm grateful to Mark for making it. Even if it took me a while to admit it.

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's… a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

It's not glamorous, okay? Forget everything you see in movies. There's no glowing skin or effortless grace. It's mostly just swollen ankles, heartburn, and a constant need to pee.

I feel like a whale. Seriously. I can barely bend over to tie my shoes. And my back hurts all the time.

And the cravings are insane. One minute I want pickles and ice cream, the next minute I want a whole pizza. It's ridiculous.

But… it's also kind of amazing. I mean, there's a tiny human growing inside me. That's pretty incredible, when you think about it.

I can feel him or her moving now, which is… weird. And kind of wonderful. It's like a little flutter, or a little kick. It makes me feel connected to the baby, even though I'm giving him or her up for adoption.

I'm also starting to feel… emotional. I'm sad about saying goodbye, but I'm also excited for the baby to have a loving home. It's a complicated mix of feelings.

Honestly, I'm mostly just tired. And uncomfortable. And anxious. But I'm also trying to stay positive. I'm trying to focus on the future. And I'm trying to prepare myself for the arrival of this little person.

It's a weird time. A really weird time. But it's also a beautiful time. And I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends. And I'm grateful for Mark and Vanessa, who are going to give this baby a wonderful life.

So yeah. Eight months pregnant. It's a lot. But I'm getting through it. One day at a time. And I'm trying to remember to breathe. And to eat pickles and ice cream. Because apparently, that's what you're supposed to do.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's *always* happening. Like, can't a girl just walk down the street without being analyzed?

Honestly? I think it's a combination of things.

First, I'm pretty sure I just have one of those faces. Like, I'm not conventionally pretty, but I'm… noticeable. I have strong features, and I don't really try to blend in. I wear what I want, I say what I think, and I don't care what anyone else thinks.

Second, I think people are curious. I'm not like most of the kids at Maplewood High. I'm a little bit weird, a little bit different. And people are always drawn to things that are different.

And third… well, let's be real. The whole pregnancy thing hasn't exactly helped. People are definitely staring *because* of that. They're whispering and judging and making assumptions. It's annoying.

I try to ignore it. I try to pretend that I don't notice. But it's hard. It makes me feel self-conscious and uncomfortable.

Sometimes, I stare back. Just to make them feel awkward. It's a little bit petty, but it makes me feel better.

But mostly, I just try to focus on my own life. I try to surround myself with people who love and support me. And I try to remember that other people's opinions don't matter.

It's my life, and I'm going to live it the way I want to. Even if that means being stared at. It's a small price to pay for being myself. And honestly, I'm kind of over it. I'm done trying to please everyone. I'm just going to be me. And if people don't like it, that's their problem.

(Rolls eyes so hard I think I pulled a muscle) Ugh. Seriously? *That* is what we're talking about now?

Okay, look. Bleek and Katrina? It's… a choice. A questionable choice. A choice that makes me deeply uncomfortable just *thinking* about it.

Bleek is… Bleek. He's sweet, I guess. But he's also kinda spacey and awkward and doesn't say much. And Katrina De Voort is… Katrina De Voort. Need I say more? She's a walking, talking stereotype. A mean girl. A Regina George wannabe.

They are, like, polar opposites. It's a disaster waiting to happen.

I mean, I'm all for people finding love, or whatever. But this just feels… wrong. It feels like a power play on Katrina's part. Like she's just trying to prove something.

And I feel bad for Bleek. He deserves someone who appreciates him for who he is, not someone who's just using him to make a statement.

Honestly, I'm predicting a lot of awkward silences and forced smiles. And probably a dramatic breakup before the night is over.

But hey, what do I know? Maybe they'll surprise me. Maybe they'll actually have a good time. But I highly doubt it.

It's just… ugh. It's a whole thing. And I'm officially over it. Can we talk about something else now? Please? Like, anything else? Even the quadratic formula sounds better than this.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a lot. This whole thing has been a crash course in, well, *me*. And it hasn't always been pretty.

I think the biggest thing I've learned is that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent and resilient, but this… this has been a whole different level. Facing this, making the decision about adoption, dealing with the judgment… it's been incredibly challenging. But I've gotten through it. And I'm still getting through it.

I've also learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. I used to think that showing emotion was a weakness. But I've realized that it's actually a strength. It takes courage to be honest about your feelings, to ask for help, to let people see the real you.

I've learned that I'm capable of a lot more compassion than I thought I was. Not just for the baby, but for Mark and Vanessa, for my dad and Bren, and even for myself.

I've learned that I'm not afraid to make difficult decisions. Even when those decisions are painful. I've learned to trust my gut, and to do what I believe is right, even if it's not what everyone else wants me to do.

And I've learned that I'm still figuring things out. I don't have all the answers. I'm still growing and changing. And that's okay.

This journey hasn't been easy. It's been messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also been incredibly rewarding. It's forced me to confront my fears, to challenge my beliefs, and to become a better version of myself.

So yeah. I've learned a lot about myself throughout this pregnancy journey. And I'm grateful for the lessons, even the painful ones. Because they've made me who I am today. And I think, despite everything, I'm okay with that. I'm still Juno MacGuff. Just… a little bit wiser, a little bit stronger, and a whole lot more grateful.

Ugh, don't even get me started on Bleeker. That kid is… a mess. A well-meaning mess, maybe, but a mess nonetheless.

Look, Katrina is a good person. She's sweet, she's smart, and she deserves someone who actually *sees* her, you know? Not someone who just wants a girlfriend because everyone else has one.

And Bleeker? He's clearly just trying to fill a void. He's awkward and insecure, and he's using Katrina to make himself feel better. He's not actually interested in *her*. He's interested in having a girlfriend. There's a difference.

It's just… frustrating to watch. Katrina is putting herself out there, being vulnerable, and he's just taking advantage of it. He's leading her on, and he doesn't even realize he's doing it.

I've been there, okay? I've had guys treat me like I'm just a prize to be won. And it sucks. It makes you feel worthless and used.

Katrina deserves better. She deserves someone who appreciates her for who she is, not someone who just wants to check her off their list.

And honestly, Bleeker is just going to end up hurting her. He's not ready for a relationship. He needs to figure himself out before he starts messing with someone else's feelings.

So yeah, I'm concerned. I want Katrina to be happy. And I don't think Bleeker is the one who's going to make that happen. It's just… obvious. And it's annoying. And I want to shake him and tell him to get his act together. But I probably won't. Because that would be weird. But seriously, Bleeker needs to get it together.

Ugh, prom. Don't even get me started. It's like… a societal construct designed to make insecure teenagers spend a lot of money on something ultimately pointless.

When you're younger, you see it in movies and it looks all magical and romantic. Like, the night your life changes forever. But then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you realize it's just… a really crowded, overpriced dance with a lot of awkwardness.

It's like everyone's trying too hard. Everyone's trying to look perfect, to have the perfect date, to have the perfect night. And it's just… exhausting.

And the pressure! The pressure to find a date, the pressure to get the perfect dress, the pressure to have fun. It's all just too much.

Plus, let's be real, most people just end up making out in the parking lot. Which, okay, fine, if that's your thing. But it's not exactly a fairytale ending.

I think once you're old enough to actually *think* about things, you realize that prom is just… a performance. It's a performance of happiness and romance and perfection. And it's not real.

It's like, you've spent your whole life being told what to do and how to be. And prom is just another example of that. It's another expectation that's placed on you.

And honestly, I'd rather spend my Saturday night doing something that actually makes me happy. Like listening to music, or watching a movie, or just hanging out with my friends.

So yeah. Prom is not cool anymore once you're old enough to go. It's just… a lot. And I'd rather skip it. It's not worth the stress. It's not worth the money. And it's definitely not worth pretending to be someone I'm not. It's just… overrated. Seriously. Overrated.

Okay. This is… hard to talk about. But you asked.

It wasn't a quick decision, you know? It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, I'll just give the baby away." It was a lot of thinking. A lot of crying. A lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

I was sixteen. I was still in high school. I didn't have a job. I didn't have a stable home. I wasn't ready to be a mom.

I knew that I couldn't give the baby the life it deserved. I couldn't provide for it financially, emotionally, or practically.

And I didn't want to bring a child into the world if I couldn't give it the best possible start.

I considered all my options. Abortion wasn't something I felt comfortable with. And keeping the baby… it just didn't seem realistic.

Adoption felt like the best option. It allowed me to give the baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for it.

It was a really difficult decision. It was heartbreaking. It still is, sometimes.

But I knew that it was the right thing to do. Not for me, necessarily, but for the baby.

I met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby, and I knew right away that they were the right people. They were kind and loving and excited about becoming parents. They made me feel comfortable and safe.

They weren't trying to replace me. They just wanted to give the baby a good home.

It's still hard. I think about the baby all the time. I wonder what it's like, what it's doing, who it's becoming.

But I know that I made the right decision. And I hope that the baby is happy and healthy and loved.

It's not a perfect situation. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's the best I could do. And I'm trying to find peace with it. It's a process. And it's something I'm still working through. But I know, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved. It just… had to be.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he just… overthinks things. And worries. A *lot*.

It's not that I don't understand his concern. He's my dad. He wants to protect me. And he's seen enough bad stuff in his life to know that not everyone has good intentions.

But he's acting like Mark and Vanessa are villains in a movie. Like they're going to swoop in and steal the baby and run off to a remote island. It's ridiculous.

I've spent a lot of time with them. I've talked to them. I've gotten to know them. They're good people. They're kind and compassionate and they genuinely want to give this baby a loving home.

And the agency is doing a thorough background check. They're making sure that everything is above board.

But Dad still doesn't trust them. He keeps asking me questions, pointing out potential red flags, and generally making me feel anxious.

It's frustrating. I know he's just trying to look out for me, but he's making things harder than they need to be.

I told him, "Dad, I'm not stupid. I've thought this through. I trust these people."

He just sighed and said, "I just want what's best for you, Juno."

And I know he does. But sometimes, what's best for me is letting me make my own decisions. And trusting me to know what I'm doing.

It's a tough situation. I love my dad, but I wish he would just relax a little bit. And trust that I'm capable of making a good choice. It's *my* life, after all. And I need to be the one in control. Even if it's scary. Especially if it's scary.

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes) Oh, *now* he brings that up. Classic Mac. Always with the timing.

It's… frustrating, honestly. He thinks I'm reckless. That I don't think things through. That I just jump into things without considering the consequences.

And maybe he's right. Sometimes.

But he doesn't understand. He doesn't understand that I'm trying to figure things out. That I'm trying to be independent. That I'm trying to live my life on my own terms.

He wants to protect me. I get that. He's my dad. But sometimes, his protection feels like… control. Like he doesn't trust me to make my own decisions.

And it's especially annoying now, considering *everything*. Like, yeah, maybe I got myself into a bit of a mess. But I'm dealing with it. I'm making the best decisions I can. And I don't need him to tell me what to do.

He says I don't know when to say when. But maybe *he* doesn't know when to let go.

It's not that I don't appreciate his concern. It's just that I need him to trust me. To believe in me. To let me make my own mistakes.

Because that's how I'm going to learn. That's how I'm going to grow. That's how I'm going to become the person I'm supposed to be.

So yeah. His comment was annoying. But I'm not going to let it get to me. I'm going to keep doing what I'm doing. And I'm going to prove to him that I can handle things. Even if it means making a few mistakes along the way. Because that's just who I am. A little bit messy, a little bit reckless, and a whole lot of determined. And he'll just have to deal with it.

Ugh. The Loring's. Don't even get me started. It's… aggressively beige. And pretentious. And just… *much*.

It's like stepping into a Stepford Wives convention. Everyone's perfectly manicured, their lawns are perfectly green, and their cars are all shiny and new. It's so… sterile.

It feels fake. Like everyone's trying too hard to be perfect. And it's just… suffocating.

I went there with Mark and Vanessa a few times, and I felt so out of place. Like I didn't belong. Like I was being judged for my clothes and my hair and my general lack of… polish.

It's not that I have anything against people who have money. It's just that I don't understand why they need to live in a gated community. Like they're afraid of the real world.

It feels isolating. Like they're trying to create their own little bubble, separate from everyone else.

And honestly, it's just kind of sad. Like they're missing out on all the good stuff that life has to offer. The messiness, the chaos, the imperfections.

I'm glad the baby will have a safe and comfortable home, but I also hope that Mark and Vanessa will make an effort to expose him or her to the real world. To show him or her that there's more to life than perfectly manicured lawns and shiny cars.

It's just… not my scene. I prefer a little bit of grit and grime. A little bit of character. A little bit of… realness. The Loring's is just… too much. Too perfect. Too fake. It gives me the creeps. Seriously.

Ugh, okay. Vanessa Loring. Right. That's… complicated.

Honestly? My first impression was… she seemed *too* perfect. Like, Stepford Wife perfect. She was really pretty, really put-together, and really… nice. Almost suspiciously nice.

I was expecting someone… I don't know, more stern? More judgmental? Someone who would look at me like I was a screw-up. But she was just… warm. And welcoming.

It was unsettling. I was used to people looking at me with pity or disapproval. Not with genuine kindness.

I remember thinking she was probably just putting on an act. That she was trying to be nice to me because she felt sorry for me.

But then she started asking me questions. Not about the pregnancy, or the adoption, but about *me*. About my interests, my dreams, my fears.

And she actually listened. She didn't interrupt, or offer unsolicited advice. She just listened.

And I started to realize that she wasn't trying to be perfect. She was just… a good person. A genuinely kind and compassionate person.

She and Mark, they just seemed… stable. Like they had their lives together. Which was intimidating, honestly. I was a mess.

But they didn't treat me like a mess. They treated me like a person. And that made a huge difference.

So, yeah. My initial impression was that she was too perfect. But I quickly realized that she was just… good. And that was a really good thing. It was a relief, actually. And it made me feel a little bit more hopeful about the whole situation. It still didn't make it easy, but it made it… less scary.

(Blushes slightly, even though you can't see it) Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive this. It was… mortifying. And kinda sweet. And confusing. All at the same time.

So, there I was, lugging around this ridiculously heavy backpack – filled with textbooks and, let's be real, a lot of unnecessary stuff – and Bleeker just… offered to carry it.

Like, out of the blue. He just walked up to me and said, "Here, let me get that."

And I was completely caught off guard. I mean, Bleeker? The quiet, awkward Bleeker? Offering to help *me*? It was… unexpected.

I think I mumbled something about being fine, and tried to refuse. But he just insisted. He was all shy and earnest, and he actually looked like he could handle the weight.

So I let him. And it was… weird. Walking next to him with him carrying my backpack. It felt… intimate.

And I kept glancing at him, trying to figure out what he was thinking. Was he just being nice? Or was there something more to it?

I had no idea. And honestly, I was too embarrassed to ask.

It was just… a moment. A small, awkward, kinda sweet moment. And it definitely made me think about Bleeker in a different light.

It was also a reminder that people are often more complex than they seem. And that sometimes, the quietest people have the biggest hearts.

So yeah. That backpack thing. It was… a thing. And it still makes me smile, even though it was also incredibly awkward. Don't tell anyone I said that. Seriously. My reputation is at stake.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's… complicated. But I'll try to explain.

Before I read that comic, I was just… stuck. I felt like everyone else was figuring things out, and I was just… existing. I was self-conscious about my body, about my clothes, about everything. I felt like a "fat dork," as you so eloquently put it.

But then I read "Most Fruitful Yuki." And it wasn't about losing weight or changing your appearance. It was about accepting yourself for who you are. It was about finding beauty in imperfection.

Yuki, she wasn't trying to be someone she wasn't. She was just being herself. And she was happy. And that was… inspiring.

It made me realize that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be quirky. It's okay to be… me.

It wasn't about suddenly loving my body. It was about realizing that my body is just a vessel. It's what allows me to experience life. And it doesn't need to conform to anyone else's standards.

It was about shifting my focus from what I *looked* like to who I *was*. And that made all the difference.

It didn't magically erase my insecurities, but it gave me a new perspective. It gave me the courage to be myself, even when it's scary.

So yeah. That comic made me feel less like a fat dork. It made me feel… human. It made me feel… okay. And honestly, that's all I ever wanted. It was a little bit of a revelation, you know? A little bit of a lightbulb moment. And it's something I'll always be grateful for. It just… clicked. And it made me feel a little less alone in the world.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me about that comic book conversation. It was… awkward. And a little bit mortifying.

But okay, if I had to guess why Mark compared me to that pregnant superhero, Supernova… I think it was about the strength thing.

He said she was strong, not because she could fly or shoot lasers, but because she was making a really difficult choice. She was choosing to give up her baby so that it could have a better life.

And I guess… that's what I'm doing too.

It's not glamorous, or heroic, or anything like that. It's just… the right thing to do. But it takes a lot of courage. And a lot of strength.

I think Mark saw that in me. He saw that I was trying to be brave, even though I was scared. He saw that I was willing to put the needs of the baby before my own.

He said Supernova was a "real hero" because she was making a selfless sacrifice. And I guess… he thinks I am too.

It's weird to think of myself as a hero. I'm just a regular teenager who made a mistake. But I guess… maybe I am a little bit strong. Maybe I am a little bit brave.

And maybe, just maybe, I'm doing something good. Even if it doesn't feel like it all the time.

It was still a really weird conversation, though. And I'm pretty sure I blushed the entire time. Don't tell anyone. Seriously. My reputation is at stake.

Okay, this is… complicated. And it's something I've thought about *a lot*. Everyone keeps asking me about open adoption, like it's the best thing ever. But honestly? It scares me.

Look, I get the appeal. The idea of the baby knowing who I am, of having some kind of relationship with me… it sounds nice, in theory. But for me, it feels… messy. And overwhelming.

I'm already struggling with the decision to give the baby up for adoption. Adding another layer of complexity, of ongoing contact, just feels like it would make things even harder.

I need to be able to move on with my life. I need to be able to heal. And I worry that an open adoption would make that impossible. It would be a constant reminder of what I gave up.

I know some people think that's selfish. But it's not about being selfish. It's about protecting myself. It's about giving the baby the best possible chance at a happy and stable life. And I think that means giving them a family who can love them unconditionally, without having to worry about me being in the picture.

Okay, so, picture this: I'm trying to have a normal conversation with Bleeker, trying to figure out if we even *have* a normal conversation to have, and then *that* happens. Vijay, the human encyclopedia, just casually drops a bomb like that.
