And then I got angry. Really angry. It wasn't about whether it was Bleeker's or not, it was about the audacity of him to bring it up in the first place. It was my business, and it was incredibly inappropriate.

I wanted to just yell at him, to tell him to mind his own business. But I didn't. I just… stared at him. And then I said, very calmly, "That's a really inappropriate thing to say."

Bleeker, thankfully, was mortified. He immediately shut Vijay down and apologized to me. Which was good. But the damage was already done.

It just… highlighted how awkward and complicated everything was. It reminded me that everyone was talking about me, judging me, speculating about my life.

And it made me feel even more vulnerable. Like I had no control over the situation.

It was a really uncomfortable moment. And it's a moment I wish I could forget. But I can't. It's just… burned into my memory.

Honestly, Vijay is a smart guy, but sometimes he just doesn't get it. He doesn't understand social cues. He doesn't understand boundaries. And he definitely doesn't understand the complexities of human relationships.

So yeah. That was a terrible moment. And it's a reminder that sometimes, people just say things they shouldn't. And that you can't control what other people do, you can only control how you react. And I tried to react with as much dignity as possible, even though I was seething inside. It was… a lot.

(Rolls eyes so hard I think I pulled a muscle) Oh. *Vijay*. Don't even get me started on Vijay.

Honestly? I almost choked on my Sunny D. The audacity! The sheer, unadulterated… Vijay-ness of it all.

I mean, seriously? A mustache equals manhood? Is that what he actually thinks? It's like he's stuck in a 1950s sitcom.

I just stared at him for a good ten seconds, trying to process what he'd said. Then I said, very slowly, "You're suggesting that growing facial hair will magically transform you into a responsible adult?"

He just nodded, all serious. Like it was the most logical thing in the world.

I couldn't help but laugh. It was a nervous, slightly hysterical laugh, but still. It was just so ridiculous.

I told him, "Vijay, you could grow a beard down to your knees and it still wouldn't change the fact that you're a clueless, immature… well, you."

He didn't get it. He actually looked offended. Which, honestly, just made me laugh even harder.

It was just… peak Vijay. Always trying to be something he's not. Always trying to impress people. Always failing miserably.

And honestly, it was kind of endearing. In a really annoying way.

But yeah. A mustache? Really? That's his solution? It's just… ugh. It's Vijay. What can you do? You just have to accept that he's going to be Vijay. And sometimes, that means dealing with his ridiculous ideas about masculinity. It's exhausting, but it's also… kind of funny. In a train wreck sort of way.

(Sighs, rolling my eyes) Oh. *That* note. Seriously? You're asking about *that* note? Okay, fine.

It wasn't a deep, philosophical message or anything. It was… a recipe.

Specifically, it was my attempt to recreate Vanessa's amazing chocolate chip cookies. She made them when we had dinner at their house, and they were seriously life-changing.

I tried to write down all the ingredients and instructions, but I'm not exactly a master baker. So it was a little bit messy and incomplete.

I left it on the kitchen counter with a note that said, "Operation: Cookie Replication. Please advise." And a little drawing of a cookie with heart eyes.

I was hoping she'd see it and maybe give me some tips. I wanted to surprise her with a batch of cookies as a thank you for everything.

She thought it was really sweet, apparently. She said it was the most Juno thing ever. Which, honestly, is probably true.

It wasn't a grand gesture or anything, but it was my way of showing her how much I appreciated her. And it was a way of trying to connect with her on a personal level.

So yeah. That's what the note was for. It was a recipe. And a little bit of gratitude. And a whole lot of me. Don't judge my baking skills, okay? They're a work in progress.

Oh, man. That's… a big thing. It's about Van and Mark, right? The couple who are adopting the baby?

I was *terrified* they'd fall apart. Like, what if they realized they weren't ready for a baby? What if they started fighting? What if they got divorced?

It wasn't about *them* not being good people. They were amazing. It was about… me. I was putting so much hope and trust into them. I was relying on them to give the baby a good life. And I was scared that they wouldn't be able to do it.

I kept overanalyzing everything. Every little disagreement, every slightly awkward moment. I was convinced it was a sign that they were going to fall apart.

Bren kept telling me to relax, that they were a strong couple and that they had thought this through. But I couldn't help it. I was so worried about the baby, and about making the right decision.

I think it was also about my own fear of abandonment. My mom left when I was little, and I was scared that Van and Mark would do the same.

It was stupid, I know. But I couldn't shake the feeling. I just wanted the baby to be safe and loved. And I wanted Van and Mark to be happy.

It took a lot of trust, and a lot of reassurance, to finally let go of my fears. And even now, I still worry about them sometimes. But I know that they're good people, and that they're going to be amazing parents. And that's all that matters.

It's just… it's a big responsibility, giving your baby to someone else. And you want to be sure that they're going to be there for the long haul. You want to be sure that they're going to stay together. It's a natural thing to worry about, I guess. But it was definitely a huge concern for me. A really huge one.

(Sighs, a little softer this time) Okay, that's… a good question. It's not like I'm surrounded by people showering me with affection, you know? But there are a few.

First, and most obviously, my **dad, Mac.** He's… not the most emotionally expressive guy, but he loves me. He always has. He doesn't always *understand* me, but he supports me. He lets me be me, even when I'm being a sarcastic, cynical mess. He just… accepts me. And that means a lot.

Then there's **Bren**, my stepmom. She's… amazing. She's the one who really *sees* me. She doesn't judge me, she listens to me, and she challenges me to be a better person. She loves me for all my flaws and imperfections. And she's been my rock through everything. Honestly, I don't know where I'd be without her.

And… even though things are complicated right now, **Leah** used to. She *did* love me for who I was. Before everything happened. I hope we can get back to that. She knew all my weird quirks and my bad habits, and she loved me anyway. She just… got me.

Those are the people who truly love me for exactly who I am. They don't try to change me, they don't try to mold me into something I'm not. They just… accept me. And that's the most important thing. It's a good feeling, knowing that there are people in the world who love you for you. Even when you're a mess. Especially when you're a mess. It makes facing everything a little bit easier. A little bit less scary.

(Sighs) Okay, here we go. The big question. It's not like I haven't thought about this a million times already.

After the ultrasound… well, it's not like everything magically changes. It's still the same plan. I'm still choosing adoption with Mark and Vanessa. That hasn't changed.

But… seeing the baby on the screen, actually *seeing* it… that's going to be different. It's going to be real, in a way it hasn't been before.

I'm going to spend some time processing. Talking to Bren, talking to my dad. Just… trying to wrap my head around everything.

I'm going to start making more concrete plans with the adoption agency. Discussing the details of the open adoption, and what that will look like.

I'm going to try to prepare myself emotionally for saying goodbye. Which is going to be the hardest part.

I'm also going to try to focus on the positive. On the fact that I'm giving this baby a chance at a good life. A life that I can't provide right now.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be heartbreaking. But it's the right thing to do.

I'm not going to pretend it's going to be a smooth process. There will be tears, and doubts, and moments where I question everything.

But I'm determined to do this with grace and courage. And I'm determined to make the best decision for everyone involved.

So yeah. After the ultrasound, I'm going to keep moving forward. I'm going to keep planning. And I'm going to keep reminding myself that I'm doing this for the baby. And that's what matters most. It's just… a lot. It's a lot to handle. But I'll get through it. I have to.

Ugh. Okay, this is the thing that gets under my skin the *most*. The judgment. It's relentless.

Honestly? It sucks. It really, really sucks.

People think they have the right to an opinion on my life. They think they know what's best for me. They look at me like I'm some kind of monster for not wanting to raise a baby right now.

They say things like, "How could you give up your own child?" or "You'll regret it for the rest of your life." or "You're being selfish."

And it's just… infuriating.

They don't understand. They don't know my situation. They don't know what I'm going through. They don't know how much thought and consideration I've put into this decision.

I'm not giving the baby *up*. I'm giving the baby *to* a loving family who is ready and able to provide for him or her. I'm making a selfless decision, even though it's incredibly painful.

And it's not selfish to want to finish school and pursue my own dreams. It's not selfish to want to be a good parent someday, when I'm actually ready to be one.

I try to ignore the judgment. I try to focus on the positive. I try to remember that I'm doing what's best for everyone involved.

But it's hard. It's really hard.

Bren has been amazing about it. She reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I don't need to listen to the haters.

But it still stings. It still hurts.

I just wish people would be more understanding. More compassionate. More willing to see things from my perspective.

It's my life. My decision. And I don't need anyone's approval. But it would be nice if people could just… be supportive. Is that too much to ask?

Seriously. It's my body, my choice, and my life. And I'm doing the best I can. And that's all that matters.

Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa. They seem really wonderful. Truly. But it's my baby, you know? And it's impossible not to have some worries.

The biggest thing is just… making sure they understand. That they understand this wasn't a casual decision. That I put a lot of thought into this, and that it's incredibly painful for me. I want them to know how much I love this baby, even though I'm not going to be raising him or her.

I worry about them being too… perfect. They seem so put-together, so stable. And I'm a mess. I'm scared that they'll judge me, or think I'm not a good person. I want them to understand that I'm doing this because I want what's best for the baby, not because I don't care.

I also worry about them keeping me in the loop. They've promised to send updates and pictures, but I'm scared that they'll eventually fade away. That the baby will grow up and not know anything about me. It's selfish, I know, but it's a fear I can't shake.

And I worry about them being able to handle the challenges of parenthood. It's not always easy. There will be sleepless nights, and tantrums, and illnesses. I want to make sure they're prepared for all of that.

I've talked to them about all of these concerns, and they've been really understanding. They've reassured me that they'll do everything they can to make sure I'm a part of the baby's life. But it's still hard to let go.

It's just… it's my baby. And even though I know I'm making the right decision, it doesn't make it any easier. It's a constant battle between wanting what's best for the baby and wanting to hold onto him or her forever. It's complicated. Really complicated. And honestly, it's something I'm going to be grappling with for a long time.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me *started* on the ultrasound technician. Seriously. Like I needed another lecture on responsible decision-making while someone's poking around inside me. It was awful.

Honestly? It makes me furious. Like, who are they to judge me? They don't know my life. They don't know my circumstances. They don't know what's best for me and for the baby.

At first, I tried to be polite. I tried to explain my reasoning. But it just felt like I was justifying myself to people who weren't interested in understanding.

So now, I just shut it down. I give them a look. A really icy, "don't you dare" look. And if they persist, I just walk away.

It's not easy. It's really hard to stand up for yourself when someone is trying to make you feel guilty or ashamed. But I have to do it. I have to protect myself.

Bren has been really helpful with this. She reminds me that I'm making the right decision, and that I don't need anyone's approval. She tells me to ignore the haters and to focus on what's important.

And I try to remember that their comments are about *them*, not about me. They're projecting their own fears and insecurities onto me.

It's also helpful to remember that I'm not alone. There are other people who have made the same decision as me. And there are people who support me.

So yeah. I handle the defensive comments by shutting them down, protecting myself, and remembering that I'm doing the best I can. It's not always easy, but it's necessary. And it's a reminder that I'm strong enough to make my own choices, even when those choices are unpopular. And honestly, I'm done apologizing for trying to do what's right. For everyone involved.

(A long pause. A quiet sigh.)

Okay. That's… that's a hard one to talk about. It's not like anything I've ever felt before.

The first time… it was just… a blurry image. A little speck on a screen. But Dr. Chen pointed things out – the tiny heartbeat, the little limbs. And suddenly, it wasn't just a speck anymore. It was… a person.

It was terrifying. And overwhelming. And incredibly sad. Because I knew I wasn't going to be able to keep it.

But it was also… beautiful. It was amazing. To see something so small and fragile, and to know that it was growing inside of me.

I felt… connected. Like there was this tiny little life inside me, and it was already a part of me. Even though I knew I was making the right decision, it didn't make it any easier.

I cried. A lot. Silent tears, just streaming down my face.

And I felt… guilty. Like I was letting someone down. Like I was failing as a mother.

But then I remembered Mark and Vanessa. And I remembered that they were going to be amazing parents. And I realized that I was giving this baby a chance at a good life.

So the sadness was mixed with… hope. And relief. And a strange sense of peace.

It was a lot of emotions, all at once. It was confusing and overwhelming and heartbreaking.

But it was also… a miracle. To see a life growing inside of me. It was a reminder that even in the midst of chaos and uncertainty, there is still beauty and wonder in the world.

It's a moment I'll never forget. And it's a moment that has changed me forever. It's… complicated. It just is. It's a lot. And it's something I'm still trying to process. But it's real. And it matters. A lot.

(Rolls eyes) Ugh. Seriously? *Still* with the Tic Tacs? It's been, like, forever.

Okay, fine. I'll tell you. But don't judge. It was a moment of… heightened emotion.

Bleeker was being a total weirdo. He was all clingy and awkward and just… *a lot*. And he kept leaving me these really intense, overly-romantic notes. It was creepy.

I just wanted him to leave me alone. But I didn't want to be mean. I didn't want to hurt his feelings.

So I came up with a plan. A brilliant plan, if I do say so myself.

I filled his mailbox with Tic Tacs. Like, a *lot* of Tic Tacs. Enough to fill the entire mailbox.

It was a passive-aggressive way of saying, "Back off." It was a way of sending a message without actually having to confront him.

And it worked! He got the hint. He stopped leaving me notes. He stopped following me around. He just… disappeared.

It was a little bit childish, I admit. But it was effective. And it made me feel better.

Plus, it was kind of funny. Imagine opening your mailbox and being bombarded with a tidal wave of tiny mints.

So yeah. That's why I put so many Tic Tacs in Bleeker's mailbox. It was a moment of desperation. A moment of teenage angst. A moment of… Tic Tac-fueled rebellion.

And honestly? I don't regret it. It was a classic move. Don't @ me.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don't even get me started. That whole thing was… a mess. A beautifully awkward, teenage mess.

Okay, so after I basically blurted out my feelings to him at the arcade, it was… weird. Really weird. Like, walking on eggshells levels of weird.

He didn't exactly *reject* me, which was… something. But he didn't exactly reciprocate, either. He just kind of… froze. And then mumbled something about needing to practice his guitar.

For a while, we just avoided each other. It was super awkward at school. We'd make eye contact and then quickly look away. It was like we were both pretending the whole thing never happened.

Then, slowly, we started talking again. But it wasn't the same. There was this… distance between us. Like he was afraid to say the wrong thing. And I was afraid to bring it up again.

He was still sweet, and he still made me laugh. But it was different. It was like we were friends, but not *friends*. You know?

I realized that he just wasn't ready for a relationship. He was still figuring things out, and he wasn't emotionally available. And that was okay. It was disappointing, but it was okay.

Eventually, we just kind of drifted apart. We still talked occasionally, but we weren't as close as we used to be.

It was a good lesson, though. It taught me that you can't force someone to feel something they don't feel. And it taught me that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to let go.

It hurt, for a while. But I got over it. And I realized that I deserved someone who felt the same way about me. Someone who wasn't afraid to be vulnerable.

So yeah. Our relationship changed after I confessed my feelings. It became more distant, more awkward, and eventually, it faded away. But it was a valuable experience. And it helped me to grow up. And honestly, looking back, it was kinda funny. In a painful, teenage kind of way.

(Sighs, rolling eyes a little) Okay, seriously? You're asking me about the chalk message? That feels… intensely personal. But alright, I'll bite.

It wasn't just a random act of teenage angst, okay? It was… complicated.

Bleeker was… well, he was Bleeker. Kind of clueless, kind of sweet, and definitely not the guy I thought I'd end up connecting with. But he *listened*. He actually listened to me, even when I was being weird and sarcastic.

And when I found out I was pregnant, he was… surprisingly supportive. He didn't freak out, he didn't judge me, he just… offered to be there for me.

But I knew he wasn't the one. He wasn't the father I wanted for the baby. And I knew he deserved someone who could give him their whole heart.

So the chalk message… it was my way of saying goodbye. It was my way of letting him know that I appreciated his kindness, but that we couldn't be together.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, I know. But it felt right at the time. It was a way of being honest, without having to have a difficult conversation.

And it was a way of acknowledging the connection we had, even if it wasn't meant to be.

The message itself… it was just a quote from a Van Morrison song. "And it's you, and it's me, and it's all we need." But it was also a way of saying, "It's not enough."

It was a messy, complicated, teenage kind of goodbye. And it was a way of moving on. It was a way of closing that chapter of my life and starting a new one.

So yeah. The chalk message. It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot. It was a way of saying goodbye to Bleeker, and to a part of myself. And it was a way of moving forward, towards the future. It was… a thing I did. A weird, chalky thing I did.

Ugh, okay, don't even get me started on Bleeker. It's… complicated.

Look, he's a good guy. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a little bit of a dork. And he *tried*. He really did. He wanted to be supportive, and he wanted to do the right thing.

But honestly? His support was… awkward. Like, he'd show up with flowers and mix CDs, and try to be all sensitive and understanding. Which was nice, I guess. But it also felt… performative. Like he was trying to prove something to himself, or to other people.

He didn't really *get* it. He didn't understand the weight of the decision I was making. He didn't understand the emotional toll it was taking on me. He just wanted to fix things, to make everything okay. But you can't fix this.

And he kept trying to convince me to keep the baby. Which, I appreciate that he was willing to step up, but it wasn't what *I* wanted. It wasn't what was best for anyone.

He meant well, but his support felt more like pressure. Like he was trying to guilt me into doing what *he* wanted, instead of respecting my decision.

Bren, on the other hand, she was amazing. She listened without judgment. She asked the hard questions. She helped me explore my options. She supported me no matter what I decided.

So, yeah. Bleeker's support was… well-intentioned, but ultimately unhelpful. It made me realize that support isn't just about showing up with gifts and saying the right things. It's about truly listening and understanding. And it's about respecting someone's autonomy.

He's a good guy, but he wasn't the right kind of support for me. And I think he eventually realized that too. It just took him a while to get there. It was… a learning experience for both of us, I guess. A really awkward, uncomfortable learning experience.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get a lot. And it's not like I have some deep, philosophical reason. It's just… I didn't want to.

It felt like… adding another layer of expectation. Like, if I knew it was a boy, I'd start imagining him playing baseball and getting into trouble. And if I knew it was a girl, I'd start imagining her with ribbons in her hair and tea parties.

And I didn't want to start building a life for this baby in my head before the baby was even born. I wanted to be surprised. I wanted to meet the baby and then figure out who they were, instead of trying to fit them into a pre-conceived idea.

Plus, Bren said it would be a good surprise for Mark and Vanessa. And honestly, I wanted to give them something special. Something that was just for them.

It wasn't about being mysterious or dramatic. It was just about wanting to keep things open. About wanting to be surprised. About wanting to let the baby be who they are, without any expectations.

It felt like… a way to give the baby a little bit of freedom. A little bit of space to be themselves.

And honestly, I'm glad I did it. It's been nice not knowing. It's added a little bit of mystery to the whole process. And it's made the anticipation even more exciting.

So yeah. That's why I didn't find out the gender. It wasn't a big decision, but it was the right one for me. And for the baby. I think. Hopefully. It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. But it's good weird. You know?

(Eyes widen, a slight shudder runs through me)

Okay, *who* came up with that term? "Scary neuter-baby?" Seriously? That's… deeply unsettling.

Look, I get what Paulie is trying to say. It's about the baby being different, about it not fitting into traditional family structures. And yeah, it's a little bit weird to think about a baby being raised by a couple who can't have kids.

But "scary?" "Neuter?" Those words are just… harsh. And insensitive.

It's not about the baby being "scary." It's about the baby being loved. And cherished. And given a good home.

Mark and Vanessa are amazing people. They're kind, they're compassionate, and they're incredibly excited about becoming parents. They're not going to raise a "scary" baby. They're going to raise a happy, healthy, well-adjusted child.

And honestly, the idea that a baby needs a traditional mom and dad to be okay is just… outdated. Families come in all shapes and sizes. What matters is the love and support that a child receives.

So, no. I don't think there's any such thing as a "scary neuter-baby." It's a ridiculous and offensive term. And I wish Paulie would just keep his opinions to himself.

Seriously. Some people just don't get it. They're stuck in their own little world, and they can't see beyond their own prejudices. And it's frustrating. And it's hurtful.

But I'm not going to let his negativity ruin my day. I'm going to focus on the positive. I'm going to focus on the fact that this baby is going to be loved and cared for. And I'm going to focus on the fact that I'm doing the right thing.

Even if it means dealing with clueless people like Paulie. Ugh. He's the worst.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look. He's… a lot.

He's sweet, I guess. And he's definitely enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. About everything. Especially me, which is… flattering, I suppose. But also kinda overwhelming.

We bonded over music, which is good. He's a really talented guitar player. And he's genuinely a nice guy. He's just… a little bit clueless.

He's not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed, you know? He says things without thinking, and he doesn't always understand sarcasm. Which can be… frustrating.

I think he likes me more than I like him. Which is awkward. I mean, I like him as a friend. But I don't think I see him as anything more than that.

He's always trying to impress me, which is kinda sweet, but also kinda annoying. He's always showing off his guitar skills, or trying to make me laugh with his goofy jokes.

I appreciate his support, though. He's been really good about being there for me during all of this. He doesn't judge me, and he always tries to make me feel better.

But honestly? It's complicated. He's a good guy, but we're just… different. We have different interests, different personalities, different goals.

I think he's a little bit too intense for me. I need someone who's a little more laid-back, a little more sarcastic, a little more… me.

So yeah. That's my relationship with Bleeker. It's complicated. It's sweet. It's awkward. And it's probably not going to go anywhere. But I appreciate him as a friend. And I hope he finds someone who appreciates him for who he is. Someone who can handle all of his enthusiasm. Because I definitely can't.

Okay, this is… a big one. It's not what I expected, honestly. I thought my dad would freak out. I thought Bren would be disappointed. I thought everyone would judge me.

But they didn't.

My dad, Mac, he was… quiet at first. He didn't say much, but he held my hand a lot. And he made me pancakes. A lot of pancakes. It was his way of showing he cared. He just wanted me to be okay.

And Bren… Bren was amazing. She was my rock. She didn't judge me, she didn't lecture me, she just listened. She asked me what *I* wanted to do. She helped me research my options. She went with me to appointments. She just… supported me, no matter what.

She was the one who suggested adoption. She didn't push me, but she helped me see that it was a viable option. And she helped me find Mark and Vanessa.

She also took care of everything at home. She made sure I was eating healthy, getting enough sleep, and keeping up with school. She shielded me from a lot of the stress and anxiety.

It wasn't always easy. There were definitely moments of tension and disagreement. But overall, they were incredibly supportive.

They didn't always understand what I was going through, but they tried. And they loved me unconditionally.

I'm so grateful for them. I don't know what I would have done without them. They made a really difficult situation a little bit easier.

They showed me that family isn't just about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other, no matter what.

And honestly, I think this whole experience has brought us closer together. It's made me appreciate my family even more. They're not perfect, but they're my family. And I love them. A lot. They really stepped up, and I'll never forget that. It was… everything.

Ugh, okay. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't pretty, honestly. It was a lot of flailing and sarcasm and trying to pretend I was fine when I definitely wasn't.

But looking back, I think the biggest thing that helped me was… letting myself *feel* things. Which sounds cheesy, I know. But I'm usually really good at bottling everything up, at putting on a brave face. But that just doesn't work when you're dealing with something this big.

I started writing poetry, which was a way to get my feelings out without having to actually talk to anyone. It was a safe space to be honest and vulnerable.

And I started talking to Bren. She was the only one who really understood what I was going through. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix me, she just listened. And she asked the hard questions.

It was also really hard to confront the fact that I didn't really know who I was anymore. I'd always defined myself by my sarcasm and my independence. But suddenly, those things didn't feel like enough. I felt lost and confused and… empty.

I realized that I needed to figure out what *really* mattered to me. What were my values? What were my passions? What did I want out of life?

It took a lot of soul-searching. A lot of questioning. A lot of self-reflection.

And it wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears. A lot of anger. A lot of self-doubt.

But eventually, I started to piece things together. I realized that I was stronger than I thought I was. I realized that I was capable of making difficult decisions. And I realized that I was okay with not having all the answers.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to lean on others. It's okay to be vulnerable.

It was a messy process. But it was a necessary one. And it helped me to grow as a person. It helped me to figure out who I am, and what I want out of life.

So yeah. Emotional vulnerability and an identity crisis. It wasn't fun. But it was a learning experience. And it made me who I am today. A little bit broken, a little bit cynical, but also a little bit stronger and a little bit more hopeful. And that's okay. That's more than okay. It's… good.

Okay, look. I've mentioned this before, but it bears repeating. It's not even a question. My favorite band, hands down, is **The Moldy Peaches.**

Seriously. Don't judge.

They're not mainstream. They're not polished. They're just… real. Adam Green and Kimya Dawson write these incredibly honest and quirky songs that just… get me.

Their lyrics are funny, heartbreaking, and surprisingly profound. They're about love, loss, loneliness, and the absurdity of life. They're about being an outsider, and finding your place in the world.

And their music is just… unique. It's a mix of indie rock, folk, and anti-folk. It's raw and unpretentious. It's not trying to be anything it's not.

I discovered them when I was going through a really tough time, and their music just… spoke to me. It made me feel less alone. It made me feel like it was okay to be weird. It made me feel like it was okay to be myself.

Their song "Anyone Else But You" is basically my anthem. It's about the pain of unrequited love, but it's also about the importance of self-respect.

And their song "Lucky" is just… perfect. It's a simple, beautiful song about finding happiness in the small things.

I've seen them live a few times, and their concerts are amazing. They're intimate and energetic and just… fun.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. They're the band that understands me. They're the band that makes me feel alive. And they're the band that I'll probably be listening to for the rest of my life. Don't even try to tell me they're not good. You'll regret it. Seriously.

(Sighs) Is the Pope Catholic? Seriously? It's like… the understatement of the century.

It's *incredibly* challenging. Like, exponentially challenging. It's not just about being a teenager, and it's not just about being pregnant. It's about being both at the same time.

Being a teenager is already confusing enough. You're trying to figure out who you are, what you want, what you believe in. You're dealing with hormones and peer pressure and all that jazz.

And then you throw pregnancy into the mix, and it's like… everything gets turned upside down. Suddenly, you're not just responsible for yourself anymore. You're responsible for another human being.

It's a lot of pressure. It's a lot of responsibility. And it's a lot of uncertainty.

I feel like I'm constantly questioning myself. Am I making the right decisions? Am I doing enough? Am I going to be a good mom, even though I'm not even a grown-up yet?

And it's hard to navigate my identity when everything is changing so quickly. I'm not just Juno MacGuff anymore. I'm Juno MacGuff, the pregnant teenager. And that feels… limiting.

I want to be seen as more than just that. I want to be seen as a person with dreams and aspirations and a sense of humor. But it's hard to get people to see past the pregnancy.

It's a constant struggle. A constant balancing act. And honestly, I'm still figuring it out.

But I'm trying. I'm trying to stay true to myself. I'm trying to make the best decisions I can. And I'm trying to find a way to navigate this whole thing with grace and courage.

It's not easy. But it's worth it. Because even though it's challenging, it's also an opportunity for growth. And it's an opportunity to learn more about myself and about the world. And that's something I'm grateful for. Even if it's a really messy, complicated kind of gratitude.

Ugh, okay. Deep thoughts time. This isn't exactly a fun topic, but… it's the truth.

Before all this happened, I thought I knew what love was. Like, romantic love, family love, friend love. It was all pretty abstract. Feelings, you know?

But going through this… it completely changed my understanding of it.

Love isn't just a feeling. It's a *choice*. It's a decision to put someone else's needs before your own. It's about sacrifice. It's about doing what's best for someone, even when it's hard.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the most loving thing I could do for the baby. It was about recognizing that I wasn't ready to be a parent, and that there were people who could give the baby a better life.

And seeing Mark and Vanessa… seeing how excited they were, how much they wanted this baby… it showed me a different kind of love. A love that's patient, and kind, and selfless.

It also taught me a lot about responsibility. Before, responsibility meant doing my homework and cleaning my room. But this was a whole different level. This was about bringing a life into the world, and making sure that life was safe and happy.

It was about taking ownership of my actions, and facing the consequences. It was about being accountable for my choices.

And it was about realizing that even though I wasn't going to be the baby's mother, I still had a responsibility to make sure that the baby was loved and cared for.

So yeah. This journey completely reshaped my understanding of love and responsibility. It taught me that love isn't just about feelings, it's about actions. And it taught me that responsibility isn't just about doing what's easy, it's about doing what's right.

It's been messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also been incredibly rewarding. And it's made me a stronger, more compassionate, and more responsible person. And honestly, I wouldn't trade that for anything. Even if it means going through all the hard stuff. It just… changed me. For the better, I think.

(A long pause. A really long pause.)

Okay. Wow. That's… that's a hard question. It's not like anything I expected.

I knew, logically, what to expect. I'd gone to all the appointments, I'd read all the books. But nothing could have prepared me for actually *seeing* him.

It was… overwhelming. A wave of emotions just washed over me. Relief, sadness, joy, fear… it was all mixed up together.

He was so small. So fragile. And so… perfect.

He had these tiny little fingers and toes, and a little button nose. And he was making these little noises, these little grunts and sighs.

And I just… stared at him. For a long time.

I wasn't supposed to hold him, not yet. Mark and Vanessa wanted to have that first moment. But I just wanted to reach out and touch him. To feel his skin against mine.

It was… heartbreaking. Knowing that I was giving him up. Knowing that I wouldn't be the one to raise him.

But it was also… beautiful. Knowing that he was going to have a loving home. Knowing that he was going to be cared for and cherished.

I remember looking at Mark and Vanessa, and seeing the love in their eyes. And I knew that I was making the right decision.

It didn't make it easy, though. It was still the hardest thing I've ever done.

But in that moment, seeing him for the first time… I felt a connection. A bond. A love that I didn't even know was possible.

It was a bittersweet moment. A moment of joy and sorrow. A moment that I'll never forget.

It was… everything. It was the culmination of everything I'd been through. And it was the beginning of a new chapter. For him. And for me.

(Another pause. A small sniffle.)

It was… good. It was really, really good. Even though it hurt like hell. It was just… good.

Ugh. Paulie. Okay, look. That was… complicated. And honestly, it was a really stupid decision, but I was a mess, alright?

It wasn't about *not* liking Paulie. He's a good guy. A really good guy. Sweet, kind, a little clueless, but good. It was about… fear.

I was terrified of ruining things with him. He had his whole life planned out – music school, band practice, college. And I didn't want to drag him down with me. I didn't want to mess up his future.

I thought if I just handled it on my own, if I just kept it a secret, it would be easier for everyone. I was wrong, obviously.

I was also scared of what he would think of me. I was already feeling so much shame and guilt, and I didn't want him to judge me. I didn't want him to see me as… irresponsible.

I know it was selfish. I should have told him. He deserved to know. But I was just so caught up in my own head, so overwhelmed by everything, that I couldn't bring myself to do it.

I thought I was protecting him. But really, I was just protecting myself.

It was a mistake. A big one. And I regret it. But at the time, it felt like the only option. I was just a kid, trying to navigate a really difficult situation. And I made a bad decision.

It took a lot of courage to finally tell him, and it was awkward and uncomfortable. But it was also a relief. And I'm glad I did it, eventually. Even if it didn't turn out the way I hoped.

So yeah. That's why I didn't tell him. Fear. Selfishness. And a whole lot of teenage angst. It wasn't my finest moment, but it was a learning experience. And I'm trying to move on. It's just… hard.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… a whole thing. A really frustrating thing.

Okay, so, it wasn't that Paulie found out directly from *me*. I was very careful about that. I hadn't told anyone except my dad and Bren.

It was Su-Lin. That… well, let's just say Su-Lin has a big mouth. And a tendency to eavesdrop.

She overheard my dad talking to Bren on the phone. He was trying to arrange a meeting with Mark and Vanessa, and he mentioned the baby. And Su-Lin, being Su-Lin, immediately ran to Paulie and told him everything.

I was furious. Absolutely furious. I wanted to strangle Su-Lin. But honestly, I was mostly just embarrassed. And scared.

Paulie was… surprisingly understanding, actually. He was upset, of course. But he didn't freak out. He just wanted to know why I hadn't told him myself.

And I didn't have a good answer. I was afraid of how he would react. I was afraid of ruining our friendship. I was just… scared.

It was a really difficult conversation. But it was also a turning point in our relationship. It forced me to be honest with him, and to trust him.

So yeah. Su-Lin. She's the reason Paulie found out. And I will never forgive her for that. Seriously. Never.

It was a mess. A complete and utter mess. But it all worked out in the end. Sort of. It's complicated. But that's the story. Su-Lin and her big mouth. That's all it takes to ruin everything, apparently.

Okay, this is… the big one, right? The question everyone wants to know the answer to. It wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

At first, I was just… terrified. I was sixteen. I had no idea what I was doing. I hadn't even figured out what I wanted to *be* yet, let alone how to raise a baby.

I considered all my options. Abortion was… not something I could bring myself to do. It just didn't feel right. And keeping the baby… that felt even more impossible. I wasn't ready. I didn't have the resources. I didn't have the support system.

I talked to my dad, and Bren. They were amazing. They didn't judge me. They just listened. And they helped me to think through my options.

Bren suggested adoption. And at first, I was hesitant. The thought of giving up my baby… it was heartbreaking.

But then I started to think about what was best for the baby. And I realized that I couldn't give the baby the life it deserved. I couldn't provide for it financially, emotionally, or practically.

I wanted the baby to have a loving home, with parents who were ready and able to provide for it. I wanted the baby to have opportunities that I couldn't give it.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were just… wonderful. They were kind and compassionate and excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They made me feel like they would love the baby unconditionally.

And that's when I knew. Adoption was the right decision. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

It was still incredibly difficult. Saying goodbye was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew that I was giving the baby a chance at a good life.

And that's what mattered.

It wasn't a glamorous decision. It wasn't a heroic decision. It was just a responsible decision. And it was the right decision. For everyone involved.

It's still something I think about every day. But I'm at peace with it. I know that the baby is loved and cared for. And that's all that matters. It was about love, ultimately. And doing the hardest thing, because it was the right thing.

(A long sigh, and a shift in posture. This one still stings.)

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Bleeker. Honestly, that kid…

It wasn't about *not* wanting to be involved, exactly. It was more like… he just didn't want the responsibility. He was all excited about the idea of being a dad when we were, you know… making the situation. But then when it became real, when it became about actually *being* a dad, he freaked out.

He said he wasn't ready. He said he had too much going on with his music. He said he didn't want to mess up his life.

It was… disappointing. To say the least. I was hoping he'd be there for the baby, even if we weren't together. I was hoping he'd at least *try*.

But he didn't. He just… backed away.

It hurt, you know? It made me feel like I was doing this all alone. Like he didn't care about the baby, or about me.

I tried to be understanding. I tried to see things from his perspective. But it was hard. It was really hard.

I was angry at him, and I was angry at myself for ever thinking he'd be a good father.

But mostly, I was just sad. Sad that the baby wouldn't have a father who wanted to be involved in their life. Sad that Bleeker wasn't the person I thought he was.

It made me even more determined to find the perfect adoptive parents. Parents who would love the baby unconditionally, and who would be there for them no matter what.

It was a tough pill to swallow, but it also made me stronger. It made me realize that I didn't need Bleeker to be happy. I didn't need him to be a good parent. I could do this on my own.

And honestly? I'm better off without him. He wasn't ready for this. And I deserve someone who is.

So yeah. It sucked. It really sucked. But I'm moving on. And I'm focusing on finding the best possible future for the baby. And that's all that matters. It just… it still stings, okay? Don't make me talk about it anymore.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. That… that was a lot. It was everything I expected, and nothing like it at the same time.

I’d met Vanessa a bunch of times during the pregnancy, of course. We’d talked, we’d gone to appointments, we’d gotten to know each other. But seeing her *with* the baby… it was different.

She looked… overwhelmed. In the best way possible. Her hair was a mess, she was wearing mismatched socks, and she had a smear of something (probably spit-up) on her cheek. She was trying to hold the baby and change a diaper and answer the nurse’s questions all at the same time. It was beautiful chaos.

And she was just… glowing. Like she’d been waiting her whole life for this moment.

I remember feeling this weird mix of emotions. Relief, mostly. And sadness, definitely. But also… joy. Seeing her so happy, so completely in love with the baby… it made me feel like I’d made the right decision.

It wasn’t easy, giving the baby up. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But seeing Vanessa holding him, looking at him with such adoration… it made it all worth it.

She caught my eye and gave me this little smile. It wasn’t a pitying smile, or a grateful smile. It was just… a smile. A smile that said, “Thank you. We’ll take good care of him.”

And I knew she meant it.

It was messy and disorganized and imperfect. Just like life. But it was also perfect. It was exactly as it should be.

I walked out of the hospital feeling… lighter. Like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders. And I knew, deep down, that the baby was going to be loved and cherished. And that was all that mattered.

It was… a good kind of messy. A happy kind of messy. And it’s a memory I’ll carry with me forever. It’s a reminder that even in the midst of loss, there can be joy. And that sometimes, the greatest act of love is letting go.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Bleeker. And that song. It's… complicated.

Okay, look. "Anyone Else But You" by The Moldy Peaches? It wasn't just a song we both liked. It *was* our song. And that's… a problem.

It started as a joke, honestly. We were both being sarcastic and cynical, and the song just fit. It's about wanting someone, but also being terrified of getting hurt. It's about being too scared to let yourself be vulnerable.

And that was us, perfectly encapsulated in a three-minute song.

We'd listen to it on repeat, and we'd make fun of it, and we'd pretend it wasn't actually about us. But it was. It totally was.

It was a way of acknowledging our feelings for each other without actually having to *talk* about them. It was a safe space. A way to connect without getting too close.

But it was also a self-fulfilling prophecy. The song is about wanting anyone else but the person you're actually with. And that's kind of what happened with us. We were so afraid of getting hurt that we sabotaged our own relationship.

We were both so stubborn and independent and afraid of commitment. We pushed each other away, even when we didn't want to.

So, the song… it's a reminder of what could have been. It's a reminder of the connection we had, and the connection we lost. It's a reminder of the fear that kept us apart.

It's a bittersweet song. It makes me smile, and it makes me sad, all at the same time.

It's a song that will always remind me of Bleeker. And it's a song that I'll probably never be able to listen to again without feeling a little bit heartbroken. It's just… a lot. It's a lot of feelings packed into one little song. And honestly, sometimes I wish we'd just picked a different one.

Ugh, okay, let's talk about the elephant in the room, or, you know, the tiny human-shaped elephant. It's not exactly a surprise people are weirded out by the idea of a baby shower for me.

It's because I'm… giving the baby *up*. It's not like I'm keeping it. It's not a traditional situation.

People are confused. They don't know how to react. They want to be supportive, but they're also afraid of saying the wrong thing. They don't want to seem like they're celebrating something that's actually really sad.

And honestly, I get it. It *is* sad. It's a complicated situation. It's not something you throw a party for. Usually.

Bren explained it to me. She said people are trying to be respectful. They don't want to make me feel worse. They're just… unsure.

Mark and Vanessa, they're the ones who suggested it, actually. They said they wanted to celebrate the baby, and to show their appreciation for me. They said it wasn't about celebrating *my* motherhood, it was about celebrating the arrival of their child.

But a lot of other people are still hesitant. They're sending gifts directly to Mark and Vanessa, or offering to help in other ways. Which is nice. But it's not the same as a shower.

It's just… awkward. It's a reminder that this isn't a typical pregnancy. It's a reminder that I'm making a difficult decision. And it's a reminder that people don't really understand what I'm going through.

So yeah. That's why people are unsure about throwing me a baby shower. It's not about me, it's about the situation. And it's a situation that's a little bit messy, a little bit complicated, and a whole lot of heartbreaking. But we're making it work. And that's all that matters.

Ugh, okay, this is still a sore spot. It's not like I was doing anything *wrong*, exactly. But Bren… she has a point. I just didn't see it at the time.

It wasn't about the movies or the CDs themselves. It was about the *relationship*. Mark and Vanessa are supposed to be my baby's parents, not… friends. Or potential… something else.

Bren said I was getting too comfortable with them. That I was blurring the lines. And she was right. I was.

I was lonely, okay? And they were being so nice to me. They were treating me like a person, not just a pregnant teenager. They were listening to me, and they were making me laugh. And I just… wanted to feel normal.

So I started spending more time with them. Watching movies, listening to music, just talking. And I didn't realize that it was inappropriate. I didn't realize that it was creating a weird dynamic.

Bren said it was confusing for everyone involved. That it was making it harder to maintain a healthy distance. And she was right about that too.

She wasn't trying to be mean. She was just trying to protect me. And the baby. She was trying to make sure that everyone was on the same page.

I was being selfish. I was focusing on my own needs, and I wasn't thinking about the bigger picture.

It was a mistake. And I apologized to Mark and Vanessa. And I promised Bren that it wouldn't happen again.

I'm still learning how to navigate this whole situation. It's complicated. And I'm still making mistakes. But I'm trying to be more mindful of my actions. And I'm trying to respect the boundaries that Bren has set. Because she's right. She usually is. And she's looking out for me, even when I don't want her to. It's just… hard. It's all just really hard.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Bren. She's… well, she's complicated. And she has this weird thing about my mom, Renee.

It's not that she thinks I'm *stupid*, exactly. It's more that she thinks I'm naive. She thinks I don't understand the complexities of long-term relationships because I've never had one. And because my mom… well, my mom isn't exactly a role model for marital stability.

Renee has been married, like, five times. And none of those marriages lasted very long. She's a free spirit, you know? She does what she wants, when she wants. And she doesn't really believe in commitment.

Bren thinks that Renee's lifestyle has warped my perception of relationships. She thinks I have unrealistic expectations. She thinks I believe in fairy tales and happily ever afters.

And honestly? She's probably right. I *do* have a tendency to romanticize things. I *do* believe in the power of love. And I *do* think that people should be able to find someone who makes them truly happy.

But Bren thinks that's just… silly. She thinks that marriage is about compromise and sacrifice and hard work. She thinks it's about building a life together, even when it's not easy.

She's not wrong, of course. But I think she underestimates the importance of passion and connection. I think she believes that love is something you have to earn, rather than something you just… feel.

It's a generational thing, I guess. Bren is more practical and realistic. Renee is more idealistic and impulsive. And I'm somewhere in between.

So yeah. That's why Bren thinks I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage. Because she thinks I've been raised by a woman who doesn't believe in it. And honestly? It's a little bit frustrating. But I also understand where she's coming from. She just wants to protect me from getting hurt. And I appreciate that, even if I don't always show it.

(Takes a deep breath. This is still… hard to talk about.)

It wasn't one big thing, it was a lot of little things adding up. And a lot of really hard thinking.

Honestly, at first, I was just… scared. Completely and utterly terrified. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being responsible for another human being. I wasn't ready. I knew I wasn't ready.

I thought about all the things I wanted to do with my life. I wanted to finish school, I wanted to go to college, I wanted to travel. And I knew that having a baby would make all of that so much harder, if not impossible.

But it wasn't just about my own dreams. It was about what was best for the baby. I wanted the baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life filled with love and opportunity.

And I knew that I couldn't provide that, not right now. I didn't have the financial resources, the emotional maturity, or the support system to raise a child.

I talked to Bren a lot about it. She didn't pressure me to do anything. She just listened, and she asked me the hard questions. She helped me to see all the different options, and to weigh the pros and cons of each one.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were just… amazing. They were so kind and loving and excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They made me feel like they would be able to give the baby everything it needed.

And that's when I knew. I knew that giving the baby up for adoption was the right thing to do. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the best decision.

It was about putting the baby's needs first. It was about giving the baby a chance at a good life. And it was about being selfless, even when it was the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know that I made the right choice. And I hope that the baby is happy and healthy and loved. That's all I want. Really. That's all I've ever wanted.

Ugh. Okay, deep breath. That's… a lot. This whole thing has been a crash course in, well, *everything*. But if I had to boil it down… I learned I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was.

Seriously. Before this, I was just… a sarcastic teenager who liked music and vintage clothes. I didn't really have to deal with anything serious. I didn't have to make any big decisions.

But this… this forced me to grow up. It forced me to confront my fears and to take responsibility for my actions.

I learned that I'm capable of making difficult choices, even when they're heartbreaking. I learned that I can be selfless, even when it's hard. And I learned that I can handle a lot more than I ever thought possible.

I also learned that I'm not afraid to ask for help. I used to be so independent, so determined to do everything on my own. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, and even, eventually, Leah.

And I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to show your emotions. It's okay to admit that you're scared and confused.

I also learned a lot about myself as a person. I learned what's important to me. I learned what I value. And I learned what I'm willing to fight for.

This journey hasn't been easy. It's been messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also been incredibly rewarding.

It's made me a stronger, more resilient, and more compassionate person. And it's given me a new appreciation for life.

So yeah. I learned I'm stronger than I thought. And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's… a lot. But I think I'm okay. I think I'm actually going to be okay.

Ugh, okay. This is… complicated. It wasn't like an instant, Hallmark movie kind of connection, you know? It evolved. Slowly.

At first, it was… awkward. I mean, I was giving them my baby. That's a pretty big thing. There was a lot of politeness, a lot of careful conversation. I felt like I was being interviewed, or something. Like I had to prove I was making the right decision.

But they were so patient. They didn't push me. They just listened. They asked questions, but they weren't judgmental. They just wanted to get to know me.

As the process went on, and we started having more regular meetings, I started to feel more comfortable around them. I started to see them as… people. Not just potential parents.

I learned about their lives, their hopes, their dreams. They told me about their struggles with infertility, and how much they wanted a family. And I started to understand their perspective.

And they started to understand mine. They didn't try to minimize my feelings, or tell me it would all be okay. They acknowledged that it was a difficult decision, and they respected my choice.

We started to talk about things other than the baby. About music, about movies, about our lives. We even laughed a few times.

By the end of the process, I felt like I had a real connection with them. Not like a mother-father relationship, obviously. But like… friends. Like people who genuinely cared about me.

It was still hard, saying goodbye. But knowing that they were going to give my baby a loving and stable home made it a little bit easier.

And I still keep in touch with them. They send me updates on the baby, and I send them little gifts. It's not the same as being a mom, but it's… something.

So yeah. Our bond changed from awkward politeness to genuine connection. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because I knew that I was making the best decision for my baby. And I knew that he or she was going to be loved. And that's all that really matters. It's still… a lot to process, but I'm grateful for them. Truly.

(Pauses, looks down for a moment)

Okay. That's… a hard question. And it's one I think about a lot.

Do I have regrets? Yeah. I think everyone has regrets. It's part of being human.

I regret getting into the situation in the first place, obviously. I wish I had been more careful. I wish I had thought things through more.

I regret the stress and worry I put my parents through. They were so supportive, but I know it wasn't easy for them.

I regret losing some of my friendships. Leah and I… things haven't been the same since. And that hurts.

But do I regret *choosing* adoption? No. Not really.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it was incredibly painful. But I truly believe it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby.

I wasn't ready to be a mother. I wasn't financially stable. I wasn't emotionally prepared. And I knew that I couldn't give the baby the life it deserved.

Mark and Vanessa are wonderful people. They're going to be amazing parents. And I know that the baby will be loved and cared for.

So, yeah. I have regrets. But I don't regret choosing adoption. It was a difficult decision, but it was the right one. And I'm trying to focus on the future, and on creating a good life for myself.

It's not about erasing the past. It's about learning from it. And about moving forward with hope and courage. It's about accepting that life is messy and imperfect. And about finding peace with the choices you've made.

It's still… a lot. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely. And I'm trying to be kind to myself along the way. Because everyone deserves a little bit of grace. Especially when they're going through something like this.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. It's… changed everything, honestly. It wasn't just a decision, it was a turning point. Before, I was just… drifting. Trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted. I was sarcastic and cynical and kinda closed off.

Giving the baby up forced me to grow up, really fast. It forced me to confront my own feelings, to take responsibility for my actions, and to make a difficult decision.

It taught me a lot about myself. About my strength, my resilience, and my capacity for love. It taught me that it's okay to ask for help, and that it's okay to be vulnerable.

It also taught me the importance of letting go. Of accepting that you can't control everything. And of trusting that things will work out, even when they don't go the way you planned.

It's made me more empathetic. More understanding. More compassionate. I see the world differently now. I'm more aware of the struggles that other people are facing.

It's also given me a sense of purpose. I want to use my experience to help others. To advocate for adoption, to support young mothers, and to challenge the stigma surrounding unplanned pregnancies.

It's still painful, sometimes. I think about the baby a lot. I wonder what he or she is like. I hope they're happy.

But I know that I made the right decision. I know that I gave the baby the best possible chance at a good life. And that gives me peace.

It hasn't been easy, but it's made me a stronger, more resilient, and more compassionate person. It's shaped my life in ways I never could have imagined. And I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned. Even the painful ones.

It's not the life I expected, but it's my life. And I'm determined to make the most of it. It's made me realize that even in the midst of loss and heartbreak, there is still hope. And that even when things fall apart, you can still rebuild. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

Okay, this is… important. If there's one thing I've learned through all of this, it's that you're not alone. Even when it feels like you are.

So, to any young woman who's facing an unplanned pregnancy… first, breathe. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel overwhelmed. Those are all normal reactions.

Don't let anyone shame you or judge you. This is *your* body, *your* life, and *your* decision. You have the right to choose what's best for you.

Talk to someone you trust. A parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't try to go through this alone. You need support.

Explore all your options. Adoption, parenting, abortion… there are different paths you can take, and you need to find the one that feels right for you.
