But I did it. I graduated. It wasn't easy, but I did it. And I'm really proud of myself.

It taught me a lot about resilience, and about the importance of having a support system. And it taught me that even when things are really hard, you can still achieve your goals.

So yeah. I finished high school while pregnant. It wasn't glamorous, it wasn't easy, but it was worth it. And it's something I'll always be proud of. Now, please don't make me relive it. It was stressful enough the first time.

Okay, this is… the big question, isn't it? The one everyone wants to know. It's not a simple answer, and it took me a long time to figure it out.

It wasn't about what anyone else thought. It wasn't about religion, or politics, or anything like that. It was about… what felt right.

I thought about abortion, I really did. And it wasn't an easy thought to dismiss. It felt… practical, in a way. Like it would solve all my problems.

But the more I thought about it, the more uncomfortable I felt. It just didn't sit right with me. It felt… wrong.

I know that sounds vague, and maybe even a little silly. But it's the truth. It was a gut feeling.

I also thought about the baby. About the potential life inside me. And I realized that I couldn't just… end it. Even though I wasn't ready to be a mom, I still felt a connection to that little person.

Adoption felt like a way to give the baby a chance at a good life. A life with parents who were ready and willing to love and care for them.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was heartbreaking, actually. But it felt like the right thing to do.

I wanted the baby to have a family. I wanted the baby to be wanted. And I knew that I couldn't provide that, not right now.

So I chose adoption. And it was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it was also the most selfless. And I think, in the end, it was the right one.

It wasn't about what was easy. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's all that really mattered. It still matters. It's not something I talk about a lot, because it's still painful. But it's a decision I stand by. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand.

Okay, this is a serious question. And honestly, it's something I've been thinking about *a lot* lately.

Absolutely. One hundred percent. A child can absolutely thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements.

Love is what matters. Not gender, not marital status, not anything else. Love, and stability, and a commitment to providing a safe and nurturing environment.

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting my baby, they're… amazing. They're kind, they're loving, and they're incredibly excited to become parents. They're going to give that baby a wonderful life. And the fact that they're a couple doesn't change that.

I've seen single parents raise happy, well-adjusted kids. I've seen same-sex couples create loving and supportive families. It's not about the *structure* of the family, it's about the *quality* of the relationships within it.

Anyone who says otherwise is just… stuck in the past. They're clinging to outdated ideas about what a family should look like.

A child needs love, support, and guidance. They need someone to believe in them, to encourage them, and to help them reach their full potential. And that can come from anyone, regardless of their gender or sexual orientation or marital status.

Honestly, I think kids who are raised in non-traditional families are often more resilient and more open-minded. They learn to appreciate diversity and to challenge societal norms.

So yeah. I firmly believe that a child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. It's not about fitting into a mold, it's about creating a loving and supportive environment where a child can grow and flourish. And that's what really matters. It's the only thing that really matters.

Ugh. Don't make me do this. It's bad enough admitting things to myself, let alone to a… well, to whatever *you* are.

Okay, fine. If I have to be honest… my biggest flaw is probably my **sarcasm.**

I know, it sounds ridiculous. It's like, my whole *thing* is being sarcastic. But it's also a defense mechanism. I use it to keep people at arm's length. To avoid getting hurt. To deflect from my own vulnerability.

It's a habit, and it's hard to break. And sometimes, it comes across as mean or dismissive, even when I don't mean it to.

I've definitely hurt people with my sarcasm. And I've definitely pushed people away.

Bren has pointed it out to me a few times. She says I need to learn to be more open and honest with my feelings, instead of hiding behind a wall of irony.

And she's right. I know she's right.

It's just… it's hard. It's easier to be sarcastic than to be vulnerable. It's easier to make a joke than to admit that you're scared or sad.

But I'm working on it. I'm trying to be more mindful of my words. I'm trying to be more empathetic. And I'm trying to let people see the real me, even if it's messy and imperfect.

It's a work in progress. But I'm determined to overcome this flaw. Because I want to be a better friend, a better daughter, and a better person. And I know that I can't do that if I'm always hiding behind a wall of sarcasm.

So yeah. Sarcasm. It's my biggest flaw. And it's something I'm trying to fix. Don't hold your breath, though. It's not going to happen overnight. I'm still me, after all. And a little bit of sarcasm is just part of who I am. But I'm trying to use it more responsibly. Okay? Is that good enough?

Ugh, okay. That's… complicated. It wasn't a *relationship* relationship, you know? It was different. But it definitely changed how I look at things.

Before meeting Mark and Vanessa, I kinda thought all relationships were about drama and messiness and… disappointment. My mom wasn't around, Leah and I were going through stuff, I hadn't really had a good romantic relationship yet. So I figured that was just how it was.

But Mark and Vanessa… they showed me a different side of things. They were so kind and supportive and understanding. They didn't judge me. They didn't try to control me. They just… accepted me for who I was.

They were genuinely excited about becoming parents, and they were so grateful for the opportunity. And they treated me with respect, even though I was just a teenager who was giving them their baby.

It made me realize that relationships don't have to be about power dynamics or manipulation or drama. They can be about mutual respect, trust, and compassion.

It also made me realize that love comes in many different forms. It's not just romantic love. It's also the love between friends, the love between family members, and the love between people who are willing to open their hearts to each other.

Seeing how Mark and Vanessa interacted with each other, how they supported each other, how they communicated with each other… it gave me hope. It made me believe that it's possible to have a healthy, fulfilling relationship.

It didn't magically fix all my problems, or make me suddenly an expert on relationships. But it did change my perspective. It made me realize that I deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. And it made me believe that I'm capable of giving that in return.

So yeah. Mark and Vanessa… they showed me what a good relationship looks like. And it's something I'll carry with me, no matter what happens in the future. It was a really important lesson, and I'm grateful for it. Even if it came with a lot of complicated feelings.

Okay, look. This is… hard to talk about. But if someone is going through what I went through, I want them to know they're not alone. And I want them to know it's okay to feel all the things.

First, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** Seriously. Talk to your parents, your friends, a counselor, anyone you trust. You don't have to go through this by yourself.

Second, **take your time.** Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with. This is *your* life, and *your* body. You have the right to choose what's best for you.

Third, **explore all your options.** Adoption, parenting, abortion… they're all valid choices. And it's important to understand what each one entails before you make a decision.

Fourth, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation, and you're going to be feeling a lot of emotions. It's okay to be scared, to be sad, to be confused. Don't beat yourself up about it.

Fifth, **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of getting through this. Even when it feels like you can't.

And sixth, **trust your gut.** If something doesn't feel right, it probably isn't. Listen to your intuition and make a decision that feels right for you.

It's not going to be easy. There will be challenges and setbacks. But you can get through this. And you deserve to be happy.

And remember, whatever you decide, it doesn't make you a bad person. It just makes you a human being. A human being who is trying to do the best they can in a difficult situation.

So yeah. Ask for help, take your time, explore your options, be kind to yourself, remember your strength, and trust your gut. That's my advice. And I hope it helps. Because honestly, you deserve all the support in the world. You really do.

Ugh, that's… complicated. It's not like a movie montage where everything magically clicks into place. It's been a slow burn, a lot of awkward silences, and a lot of learning to understand each other.

When I was little, my dad was just… Dad. He was the provider, the fixer, the one who took me to the park. He wasn't really good at the emotional stuff. He's a pretty quiet guy, you know? He shows his love through actions, not words.

As I got older, and especially as I became a teenager, our relationship got strained. I started to pull away, and he didn't really know how to reach me. We argued a lot. About school, about my friends, about everything.

Then, when I got pregnant… that was a turning point. He was shocked, obviously. But he didn't yell or get angry. He just… looked sad. And then he told me he loved me, and that he would support me no matter what.

That meant a lot. It meant everything, actually.

Since then, our relationship has gotten a lot better. We still don't talk about everything, but we're more open with each other. He's learned to listen more, and I've learned to be more patient.

He's been incredibly supportive throughout this whole adoption process. He's gone with me to appointments, he's helped me with the paperwork, and he's just been there for me, emotionally.

I think he's realized that I'm not a little girl anymore. I'm a young woman, and I'm capable of making my own decisions. And he's started to treat me with more respect.

I've also realized that he's not perfect. He's made mistakes. But he's a good man. And he loves me, in his own way.

Our relationship is still evolving, but it's getting stronger every day. It's not always easy, but it's worth it. He's my dad. And I love him. Even when he's being annoying. Especially when he's being annoying. It's just… our thing. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Ugh, okay, don't make me sound like some kind of literary genius. I'm not. I just… write stuff.

But alright, if you want to know how I got into it… it started with journaling, actually. When I was younger, I was a really angsty kid. Shocking, I know. And I needed a way to get my feelings out. So I started writing in a journal.

At first, it was just a bunch of random thoughts and complaints. But over time, it started to evolve into something more. I started experimenting with different writing styles, and I started trying to express myself in more creative ways.

Then, in eighth grade, I took a creative writing class. And that's where I really started to develop my skills. My teacher, Mr. Peterson, was amazing. He encouraged us to take risks, to experiment with different forms, and to find our own voices.

He introduced me to a lot of different writers, like Sylvia Plath and Kurt Vonnegut and Margaret Atwood. And he taught me how to use language in a more effective way.

I also read a lot. I've always been a voracious reader. And I think that reading has had a huge impact on my writing. It's exposed me to different styles and techniques, and it's inspired me to try new things.

And honestly, a lot of it is just practice. The more you write, the better you get. It's like any other skill.

I also get a lot of inspiration from music. I listen to a lot of indie rock and folk music, and the lyrics often spark ideas for my own writing.

So yeah. Journaling, creative writing class, reading, practice, and music. That's how I developed my creative writing skills. It's not a glamorous process, but it's rewarding. And it's a way for me to express myself and to make sense of the world. And honestly, it's a pretty good way to spend my time. It's better than, like, watching reality TV, anyway. Though, don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, this is… not a fun topic. But it's real. The judgment. The stares. The whispers. It was awful. Honestly, it still is, sometimes.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I pretended it didn't bother me. But it did. It really did. It felt like everyone was looking at me, judging me, condemning me.

I got a lot of side-eye at school. Some people were outright mean. And even people who were trying to be nice sometimes said things that were hurtful. Like, "Oh, honey, what happened?" or "You're so young."

It made me want to disappear. To just crawl into a hole and never come out.

But then Bren helped me realize that their judgment said more about *them* than it did about *me*. She said that people are often afraid of what they don't understand. And that they project their own insecurities onto others.

She also reminded me that I wasn't alone. That there were other pregnant teenagers out there. And that I deserved to be treated with respect, regardless of my situation.

So I started to stand up for myself. I started to challenge the negative stereotypes. I started to talk openly about my experience.

It wasn't easy. It took a lot of courage. But it was empowering.

I also found support in unexpected places. Some of my friends were incredibly supportive. And even some of the teachers at school were really understanding.

And I learned to focus on the people who loved and supported me, and to ignore the haters.

It's still a work in progress. I still get judged sometimes. But I'm learning to be more resilient. I'm learning to not let other people's opinions define me.

I'm learning to be proud of who I am, and to own my story.

It's not easy being a pregnant teenager. But it's not something to be ashamed of. It's a part of my life. And I'm going to face it with courage and grace. And I'm going to show the world that I'm more than just a statistic. I'm a person. And I deserve to be treated with respect.

So yeah. That's how I dealt with the stigma and judgment. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because I learned that my worth isn't determined by other people's opinions. It's determined by who I am. And I'm pretty okay with who I am. Even with all the messiness.

Ugh, okay, that's a loaded question. Do I regret being outspoken and honest? Sometimes. Definitely sometimes.

It's gotten me into trouble more times than I can count. It's burned bridges. It's made people angry. It's made things awkward.

There have been times when I've wished I'd just kept my mouth shut. When I'd wished I'd just gone along with the crowd. When I'd wished I hadn't said what I was thinking.

But then I think about it, and I realize that I wouldn't be me if I wasn't outspoken and honest. It's just who I am. It's part of my personality.

And honestly, I'd rather be disliked for being myself than liked for being someone I'm not.

It's not always easy, though. It takes courage to speak your mind, especially when you know it's going to be unpopular. And it takes a lot of self-confidence to stand up for what you believe in.

But I think it's important. I think it's important to be authentic. I think it's important to be true to yourself.

And I think it's important to challenge the status quo. To question authority. To speak truth to power.

So yeah, I regret it sometimes. But mostly, I'm proud of being outspoken and honest. It's what makes me, me. And I wouldn't trade that for anything. Even if it means getting into trouble every now and then. It's just… who I am. And I'm learning to accept that. And maybe, just maybe, the world needs a few more people who aren't afraid to speak their minds. Even if it's a little bit messy.

Ugh. Okay, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's something I've been wrestling with *a lot* lately.

Honestly? It's not easy. It's a constant battle. People are always going to have opinions, especially about someone like me, making the choices I'm making. And it's tempting to just give in, to try to please everyone, to be what they want you to be.

But I've learned that you can't. You just can't. Because if you try to be everything to everyone, you end up losing yourself.

So, how do I navigate it? It's a few things.

First, I remind myself of my values. What's important to *me*? Honesty, independence, compassion. Those are my guiding principles. And if a decision aligns with those values, then I know I'm on the right track, even if other people disagree.

Second, I surround myself with people who support me. Bren, my dad, even Leah, when she's being supportive. People who love me for who I am, flaws and all. Their opinions matter to me, because they genuinely care about my well-being.

Third, I learn to tune out the noise. The judgment, the criticism, the negativity. It's easier said than done, but I try to focus on what *I* think and feel, rather than what other people think and feel.

And fourth, I remind myself that I'm not perfect. I'm going to make mistakes. I'm going to stumble and fall. But that's okay. It's part of being human.

It's about finding that balance between listening to advice and trusting your own instincts. It's about being open to feedback, but not letting it define you.

It's about remembering that you are the only one who can truly know what's best for you.

It's a work in progress, honestly. I still struggle with it sometimes. But I'm getting better at it. And I'm learning to be more confident in my own decisions.

Because at the end of the day, the only person I have to answer to is myself. And I want to be able to look myself in the mirror and say, "I did the best I could. And I stayed true to who I am." And that's all that really matters.

Okay, you're asking the big questions now, huh? It's not like I've had a lot of time to sit around and philosophize, but I've definitely thought about this stuff. Especially lately.

If I had to pick a few values that are most important to me… it would be **honesty, independence, and compassion.**

**Honesty** is huge. I need to be able to trust people, and I need to be able to be myself. I don't want to pretend to be someone I'm not, and I don't want to surround myself with people who aren't genuine. It's about being real, even when it's hard.

**Independence** is also really important. I want to be able to make my own decisions, and to live my life on my own terms. I don't want to be controlled by anyone. I want to be free to be me. It's about being self-reliant and not needing anyone to tell me what to do.

And **compassion**… I think it's important to be kind to others. To try to understand their perspectives. To offer a helping hand when they need it. It's about recognizing that we're all in this together, and that we all deserve to be treated with respect.

Those values aren't always easy to live by. Sometimes, it's easier to lie, or to conform, or to be selfish. But I try. I really do.

I think those values are what make me… me. And they're what guide my decisions. They're what help me to navigate the world.

And they're what I hope to pass on to others. Because I think if everyone lived by those values, the world would be a much better place. It's a simple idea, but it's a powerful one. And it's something I believe in. Deeply.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. There were a lot of challenges. But I think the biggest one wasn't the physical stuff, like the morning sickness or the exhaustion. It was the **loneliness.**

Everyone was supportive, don't get me wrong. Bren was amazing, my dad tried his best, and even some of my friends were understanding. But there was still this feeling of being… alone.

Like, no one could truly understand what I was going through. No one could understand the fear, the uncertainty, the guilt.

Leah… well, Leah kind of drifted away. She didn't know how to handle it, and I didn't blame her. But it still hurt. It felt like I was losing my best friend at the worst possible time.

And then there was the judgment. The whispers, the stares, the assumptions. It felt like everyone was looking at me differently. Like I was some kind of outcast.

It was hard to feel like a normal teenager when I was carrying a baby. It was hard to go to school, to hang out with my friends, to just… live my life.

I felt like I was carrying this huge secret, and I was afraid to share it with anyone. I was afraid of being judged, of being rejected, of being alone.

So I kind of shut down. I withdrew from my friends, I stopped doing the things I loved, and I just tried to get through each day.

It was a really dark time. And it was the loneliness that made it so hard. It was the feeling of being isolated and alone in the world.

It took a lot of courage to reach out for help. To talk to Bren, to talk to Mark and Vanessa, to talk to a counselor. But it was the best thing I ever did.

Because I realized that I wasn't alone. There were people who cared about me, who supported me, and who wanted to help.

And that made all the difference. It helped me to get through the toughest times. And it helped me to realize that even in the darkest of moments, there is always hope. But yeah… the loneliness. That was the hardest part. Definitely.

(A long pause. This one… this one hits different.)

Okay. Wow. That's… a big question. Even though I *am* giving the baby up for adoption, just knowing I carried him, knowing I created a life… it's changed everything.

Before, I was so focused on myself. On my own problems, my own dreams, my own future. I was cynical and sarcastic and I didn't really care about much beyond getting through the day.

But being pregnant… it forced me to grow up. It forced me to think about someone other than myself. It forced me to take responsibility for my actions.

And it made me realize that life is precious. That it's a gift. And that it's not something to be taken for granted.

It's also made me more empathetic. I feel more connected to other people. I understand that everyone is fighting their own battles. And I want to be a source of support and kindness for those around me.

It's made me realize that even though I'm not raising this baby, I'm still a part of his or her life. And that's a really powerful feeling.

It's also made me appreciate my own mom, even the one who isn't around much. I understand now how hard it is to be a mother. And I have a newfound respect for all the mothers out there.

It's… complicated. It's bittersweet. It's heartbreaking. But it's also beautiful.

It's made me realize that even in the midst of loss and sadness, there is still hope. And that even though life doesn't always go according to plan, it can still be good.

So yeah. Being a mother, even in this unconventional way, has changed my perspective on life. It's made me a stronger, more compassionate, and more grateful person. And it's something I'll never forget. It's… it's everything, really. It's changed everything.

Ugh. Self-doubt. My constant companion. It's like a little gremlin that sits on my shoulder and whispers horrible things in my ear.

Honestly? It's *really* hard. I'm good at being sarcastic and independent, but underneath all that, I'm just… insecure.

When I start to doubt myself, I usually try to distract myself. I'll listen to music, or watch a movie, or hang out with Bren. Anything to get my mind off things.

But that doesn't always work. Sometimes, the self-doubt just keeps creeping back in.

So then I try to talk to someone about it. Bren is really good at listening. She doesn't try to fix things, she just lets me vent. And she reminds me of my strengths.

I also try to remind myself of all the things I've accomplished. It's easy to focus on your failures, but it's important to remember your successes too.

And I try to be kind to myself. I tell myself that it's okay to make mistakes. It's okay to not be perfect. And it's okay to feel scared and uncertain.

It's a process. It's not something that happens overnight. But I'm learning to be more compassionate towards myself.

I also have a little mantra that I repeat to myself when I'm feeling particularly doubtful. It's just a simple phrase: "You are enough."

It sounds cheesy, I know. But it helps. It reminds me that I'm worthy of love and respect, even when I'm feeling lost and confused.

So yeah. Distraction, talking to someone, remembering my accomplishments, being kind to myself, and repeating my mantra. That's how I deal with moments of self-doubt. It's not always easy, but it's worth it. Because you deserve to believe in yourself. Even when it's hard. Especially when it's hard.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. But seriously? It's… everything. It's *huge*.

I used to think I was totally independent. Like, I didn't need anyone. I could handle everything on my own. Which is, like, a classic teenage delusion.

But this whole situation… the pregnancy, the adoption… it's shown me just how much I need other people.

I wouldn't have gotten through it without Bren. She's been my rock. She's listened to me, she's supported me, she's helped me make decisions. She's just… been there.

And even though things are complicated with Leah right now, I miss her. I miss having someone to talk to, someone to laugh with, someone to just… be with.

And even my dad, who's not exactly the most emotionally expressive guy, has been really supportive. He's been trying to understand, and he's been doing his best to be there for me.

I've also realized how important it is to have a community. To be surrounded by people who care about you, who believe in you, and who will support you no matter what.

It's not about needing to be rescued. It's about having people to share your joys and your sorrows with. It's about having people to lean on when you're feeling down. It's about having people to celebrate with when you're feeling up.

It's about knowing that you're not alone.

I think a lot of people underestimate the importance of community. They think they can go it alone. But they can't. We all need each other.

So yeah. Community and social support are incredibly important to me. They're essential. They're what get me through the day. And I'm incredibly grateful for the people in my life who support me. They're the ones who make me feel like I can handle anything. And honestly, without them, I don't know where I'd be.

Ugh. Okay, deep breath. That's… a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know?

But if I had to pick one lesson… the most important thing I learned through all of this was that **you are stronger than you think you are.**

Seriously. I went into this feeling completely overwhelmed and terrified. I didn't know how I was going to cope. I didn't know how I was going to make it through.

But I did.

I faced a lot of difficult decisions. I had to deal with a lot of judgment. I had to be brave and honest and vulnerable.

And I realized that I was capable of more than I ever thought possible.

I learned that I could handle anything life threw at me. I learned that I could rely on myself. And I learned that I could find strength in the face of adversity.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears and a lot of sleepless nights. But I got through it. And I came out on the other side a stronger, more resilient person.

And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to lean on others. It's okay to not be perfect.

This whole experience forced me to grow up faster than I was ready to. But it also taught me a lot about myself. And it taught me a lot about life.

So yeah. You are stronger than you think you are. That's the most important lesson I learned. And it's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a lesson that I hope everyone learns. Because everyone deserves to know that they're capable of amazing things. Even when they don't believe it themselves.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Honestly, I haven't really thought that far ahead. I'm still trying to figure out what I want for dinner, let alone a career.

But… maybe.

I've always loved writing. It's a way for me to express myself, to make sense of the world, and to connect with others. I love the way words can be used to create images, to evoke emotions, and to tell stories.

I'm not sure if I'm good enough to make a career out of it, though. It's a competitive field, and I'm not exactly known for my confidence.

But I've been getting a lot of encouragement from my English teacher, Mr. Harrison. He says I have a unique voice and a talent for storytelling. And Bren thinks I should pursue my passions.

So, I'm considering it. Maybe I'll take some writing classes in college. Maybe I'll try to get my work published. Maybe I'll just keep writing for myself, as a way to stay sane.

I don't know. It's scary to think about making a career out of something you love. What if you fail? What if you're not good enough?

But I think it's worth a try. I think it's important to pursue your passions, even if they're a little bit scary.

So yeah. Maybe. I might pursue a career in writing. It's not a definite plan, but it's something I'm considering. And who knows? Maybe someday you'll be reading a novel written by Juno MacGuff. Don't laugh. It could happen. It's a long shot, but… maybe.

Ugh, okay, this is a sensitive topic. It took *forever*. And it involved a lot of back and forth with Mark and Vanessa. It wasn't like I got to just pick whatever I wanted, you know? It had to be something everyone agreed on.

I had a whole list of names I liked. Mostly indie musician names, like Joni or Billie. But Vanessa wanted something more traditional. And Mark just wanted something that sounded good.

We went back and forth for weeks. It was exhausting.

Then, one day, Vanessa mentioned her grandmother's name. Her grandmother's name was **Hazel.**

And it just… clicked.

It's a classic name, but it's not *too* classic. It's a little bit quirky, a little bit vintage. And it just felt right.

It reminded me of hazel eyes, and hazelnut coffee, and warm autumn days. It felt… gentle.

Mark liked it too. And even I, despite my initial preference for more unconventional names, fell in love with it.

So, Hazel it was.

It's a little bit sad, not getting to actually *raise* Hazel. But knowing that she has a loving family, and a beautiful name, makes it a little bit easier.

It's a good name. A strong name. A hopeful name. And I think it suits her perfectly. Even though I haven't even met her yet.

So yeah. Hazel. That's the name we chose. And I think it's a perfect name for a perfect little girl. Even if she's not *my* little girl, in the traditional sense. She'll always be special to me. Always.

Ugh. "Cope" is a strong word. It was… a lot. A *lot* of everything. It wasn't like riding a rollercoaster, it was like being strapped to a rocket that was constantly changing direction.

Honestly, the first few weeks were the worst. It was a mix of relief, sadness, guilt, and fear. I felt like I was constantly crying. And I couldn't sleep. And I didn't want to talk to anyone.

Bren was a lifesaver. She just… let me feel my feelings. She didn't try to fix things, or tell me everything was going to be okay. She just sat with me and listened. And she made me tea. A lot of tea.

I also started journaling. It helped to get my thoughts and feelings out of my head and onto paper. It was like talking to a friend, but without having to worry about being judged.

And seventh, **don't give up on your dreams.** This doesn't have to be the end of your story. You can still finish school, pursue your passions, and build a life you love.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be the hardest thing you've ever done. But you can do it. And you're not alone.

There are people who care about you and want to help. Reach out to them. And remember that you deserve to be happy. Even in the midst of chaos.

And honestly? It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to just… feel. Just remember to be kind to yourself, and to trust your instincts. You've got this. I believe in you. Even if you don't believe in yourself right now.

My biggest fear wasn't about the physical stuff, like the labor or the delivery. It wasn't even about the paperwork, as awful as that was.

It was about… regretting it.

Like, what if I gave the baby up and then spent the rest of my life wondering "what if?" What if I made the wrong decision? What if I couldn't stop thinking about him or her? What if I was just… miserable?

It felt like I was giving up a part of myself. And I was terrified that I would never be able to get it back.

I kept imagining seeing the baby years later, and feeling this overwhelming sense of loss. Or feeling like I had failed as a mother.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. She said it was normal to have those fears. She said that it was okay to grieve. And she said that it was important to focus on the fact that I was doing this for the baby, to give him or her the best possible life.

But it didn't make the fear go away. It just… lessened it a little bit.

I think what helped the most was meeting Mark and Vanessa. They were so kind and loving and genuine. And they made me feel like my baby would be safe and happy with them.

But even now, sometimes I still have those doubts. It's a process. And it's not easy.

But I'm trying to trust that I made the right decision. And I'm trying to focus on the future, and on all the good things that are to come.

So yeah. Regret. That was my biggest fear. And it's still something I struggle with. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to believe that even though it's hard, it's the right thing to do. It has to be.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Ugh, okay, this story. Everyone always asks about Bleeker.

It was… a process. I needed a name for the father in the adoption paperwork, right? And he didn't want to be involved, which, honestly, was fine by me. But they needed *something*.

So I started flipping through the Yellow Pages. Seriously. I was looking for a last name that sounded… unremarkable. Like, a name that wouldn't draw attention.

And I landed on "Bleeker." It just… sounded bland. And a little bit sad. Which felt appropriate, considering the circumstances.

It also reminded me of a street in New York City. Which felt kind of cool and mysterious.

I told Bren, and she just started laughing. She said it was the most Juno thing she'd ever heard.

And honestly, she was right. It was a completely random, slightly ridiculous choice. But it felt right at the time.

It's become a bit of a running joke now. Everyone asks about Bleeker. And I just shrug and say, "He's a guy. He has a name."

It's a weird part of my story, I guess. But it's a part of my story. And it's a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there's always room for a little bit of absurdity.

So yeah. That's how I came up with the name "Bleeker." It was a completely random, slightly ridiculous choice. And I wouldn't have it any other way. It's just… Bleeker.

Okay, good question. It's not something I talk about a lot, but… punk just *got* me. Still does, honestly.

It wasn't about the mohawks or the safety pins, though those were kinda cool. It was about the attitude. The rebellion. The feeling of being an outsider.

Growing up in Maplewood, everything felt so… cookie-cutter. Everyone was trying to fit in, to be normal. And I just… didn't. I never felt like I belonged.

Punk was a place where it was okay to be different. Where it was okay to be angry. Where it was okay to question everything.

It was about challenging the status quo. About rejecting conformity. About speaking your mind, even if it meant being unpopular.

The music was raw and energetic and honest. It wasn't polished or perfect. It was real. And it resonated with me.

I loved the DIY ethic of punk. The idea that you didn't need a lot of money or resources to create something meaningful. You just needed passion and creativity.

I started listening to bands like The Clash, The Ramones, and Bikini Kill. And I started to feel like I wasn't alone. Like there were other people out there who felt the same way I did.

Punk gave me a voice. It gave me a sense of community. And it gave me the courage to be myself, even when it was hard.

It's not just music, it's a whole culture. A way of life. And it's something that's shaped who I am today. It taught me to question everything, to stand up for what I believe in, and to never apologize for being myself. And honestly, that's a pretty good lesson to learn. Even if it means wearing ripped jeans and listening to loud music.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a complicated question. It's not something I think about all the time, but it's definitely shaped me.

My mom leaving when I was little… it messed me up, honestly. It made me really scared of abandonment. Like, if someone I loved could just walk away once, they could do it again.

So I built walls. I didn't let people get too close. I kept my emotions hidden. I was afraid of getting hurt.

And it definitely affected my relationship with Leah. I was so afraid of losing her that I probably pushed her away sometimes. I was clingy and demanding and… just a bad friend.

I think I also had a hard time trusting people. I always expected the worst. I always assumed that things would fall apart.

It took me a long time to realize that my mom's decision wasn't about me. It was about her. And it took me even longer to learn to trust again.

Bren helped a lot with that. She showed me that not all adults are unreliable. She was consistent and supportive and loving. And she taught me that it's okay to be vulnerable.

But it's still something I struggle with. I still have moments where I feel anxious and insecure in my relationships. I still have a tendency to push people away.

But I'm working on it. I'm learning to trust again. I'm learning to let go of my fears. And I'm learning to appreciate the people who are in my life.

It's not easy. But it's worth it. Because I know that healthy relationships are important. And I know that I deserve to be loved and supported.

So yeah. My parents' divorce definitely impacted my relationships. It made me scared and insecure. But it also taught me the importance of trust, vulnerability, and self-love. And it's something I'm still learning to navigate. It's a process. And it's not always pretty. But it's real.

Ugh, okay, this is awkward. Talking about myself is never my favorite thing. But alright, I'll try.

I think what makes my story… different, is that it's not a typical teenage drama. It's not about popularity or prom or getting the boy. It's about something much bigger.

It's about facing a really difficult situation, and making a really difficult decision. It's about growing up faster than I ever expected to.

It's about being honest with myself and with others, even when it's scary. It's about taking responsibility for my actions.

And it's about finding strength in unexpected places. In my stepmom, Bren. In the couple who are adopting the baby, Mark and Vanessa. And even in myself.

I think a lot of people can relate to the feeling of being lost or confused or overwhelmed. And I think my story shows that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to make mistakes.

It's not a perfect story. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's real. And I think that's what makes it special.

I'm not trying to be a hero or an inspiration. I'm just trying to navigate my life the best way I can. And I think that's something that a lot of people can connect with.

It's not about the pregnancy, or the adoption. It's about the journey. It's about the growth. It's about the resilience. It's about finding your own voice and standing up for what you believe in.

So yeah. I think what makes my story unique is that it's honest. It's raw. And it's real. And I think that's something that people can appreciate. Even if it's a little bit uncomfortable. It's just… my story. And I'm trying to own it. And that's all I can do.

Ugh, good friends are hard to come by, you know? Especially now. But when you find a good one… hold onto them for dear life.

Okay, so what do I value? First, **honesty.** I need someone who's going to tell me the truth, even when it's hard to hear. No sugarcoating, no BS. Just straight up honesty.

Second, **loyalty.** Someone who's got your back, no matter what. Someone who's not going to talk behind your back or betray your trust.

Third, **a good sense of humor.** Life's too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who doesn't take themselves too seriously.

Fourth, **understanding.** Someone who gets me, even when I'm being weird or complicated. Someone who doesn't judge me for my flaws.

And fifth, **the ability to just *be* with me.** Someone who's comfortable with silence. Someone who doesn't need to fill every moment with conversation. Someone who can just sit with me and watch a movie, or listen to music, or just… exist.

I also appreciate someone who's independent. I don't need a friend who's clingy or needy. I need someone who has their own life, their own interests, and their own friends.

Basically, I need someone who's real. Someone who's authentic. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But a good friend is worth their weight in gold. And I'm lucky to have a few friends who fit the bill. Even if things are… complicated right now. It's the quality, not the quantity, that matters. And a good friend is someone who makes you feel like you can be yourself, without having to apologize for who you are. That's what I look for. Always.

Ugh. Okay, this is… complicated. It's not like it's been all sunshine and rainbows. It's definitely shaken things up.

With Leah… it's been the hardest. We used to be inseparable, but after I told her I was pregnant, things just… changed. She didn't know how to react. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. She said she was busy, but I could tell it was more than that. She was scared, I think. Scared of what it meant for our friendship. Scared of what it meant for me. We're talking again now, but it's not the same. It's… strained.

My dad and Bren have been amazing, though. They've been so supportive and understanding. They haven't judged me, and they've been there for me every step of the way. Bren especially has been a rock. She's helped me navigate the medical stuff, the emotional stuff, everything. I don't know what I would have done without her.

My friends at school… it's been a mixed bag. Some of them have been really supportive, and some of them have just… disappeared. I've gotten a lot of whispers and stares, and a few judgmental comments. It's not fun. It makes me feel like an outsider.

But it's also made me realize who my real friends are. The ones who stick around, the ones who don't judge me, the ones who just want to be there for me. Those are the friends I'm holding onto.

It's been a wake-up call, honestly. It's made me realize that relationships are fragile, and that you have to work at them. And it's made me appreciate the people who are there for me, no matter what.

It's been hard, but it's also been a learning experience. It's taught me a lot about myself, and about the people in my life. And it's made me stronger. Even if it doesn't always feel like it. It's just… a lot. A whole lot. And I'm still figuring it out.

Okay, this is getting deep again. But alright, I'll try to articulate it. It's not like I've sat down and written a manifesto or anything. It's just… stuff I believe in.

First, I think **authenticity** is really important. Being true to yourself, even when it's hard. Not trying to be someone you're not. I've seen too many people try to fit in, and it always ends badly.

I also believe in **compassion**. Trying to understand other people's perspectives, even if you don't agree with them. Being kind and empathetic. The world needs more of that, honestly.

I think **independence** is crucial. Being able to think for yourself, to make your own decisions, to not rely on others to tell you what to do. It's not about being anti-social, it's about being self-sufficient.

I believe in **questioning everything**. Not just accepting things at face value. Asking why. Challenging the status quo. Thinking critically.

And I believe in **finding beauty in the mundane**. Like, appreciating the small things. A good song, a beautiful sunset, a funny conversation. Life is full of little moments of joy, if you just take the time to notice them.

I also think it's important to **be skeptical of authority**. Just because someone is in a position of power doesn't mean they're always right. You have to think for yourself and make your own judgments.

And finally, I believe in **the power of music**. It's a universal language. It can connect people, inspire them, and heal them. It's a force for good in the world.

Those are some of the values and beliefs that shape my worldview. They're not always easy to live by, but they're important to me. They're what guide my decisions and help me to make sense of the world. And they're what make me… me. It's a work in progress, obviously. But I'm getting there. I think.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'm willing to talk about it.

Choosing a name was *hard*. Like, surprisingly hard. It felt like such a big decision. Like, this little person is going to have to live with this name for the rest of their life. No pressure, right?

I went through a million different names. I wanted something unique, but not too weird. Something classic, but not too common. Something that felt… right.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. And I talked to Mark and Vanessa. They were really open to my suggestions.

Eventually, we settled on **Hazel**.

It wasn't a name I had originally considered, but Vanessa suggested it. And it just… clicked.

Hazel is a nature name, which I like. It's the name of a tree, and I've always been drawn to nature. It feels earthy and grounded.

But it also has a bit of a vintage feel to it, which I also like. It reminds me of my grandmother, Elsie.

And it just sounds… beautiful. It's a soft, gentle name. And I think it suits a little girl. Or a little boy, honestly. It's a pretty gender-neutral name.

But the biggest reason I chose Hazel is because it reminded me of my Nana Rose. She had hazel eyes. And she was the kindest, most compassionate person I've ever known.

I wanted my baby to have a name that honored her memory. A name that would remind me of her strength and her kindness.

So yeah. Hazel. It's a name that means a lot to me. It's a name that I hope will bring my baby joy and happiness. And it's a name that will always remind me of the woman who taught me the importance of kindness and compassion. It felt like a little piece of her would always be with the baby, even though I wasn't going to be raising them. It was… important. Really important.

Ugh, okay. Deep breaths. That's… a lot to unpack. This whole thing was a crash course in life, honestly.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Seriously. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent and resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Facing my fears, making difficult decisions, dealing with judgment… it pushed me to my limits. And I survived.

I learned that vulnerability isn't a weakness. It's actually a strength. Allowing myself to be scared and sad and confused, and letting other people see that… it was terrifying, but it was also incredibly liberating.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to think I had to do everything on my own. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even Mark and Vanessa. And leaning on them didn't make me weak, it made me stronger.

I learned that people are complicated. There's good and bad in everyone. And you can't judge people based on first impressions.

I learned that there's no such thing as a perfect solution. Every decision has its consequences. And sometimes, you just have to choose the least bad option.

I learned that love comes in many forms. The love of a parent, the love of a friend, the love of a couple who are desperate to start a family… it's all different, but it's all powerful.

And I learned that even in the midst of chaos and heartbreak, there is still hope. And that even when things are falling apart, you can still find beauty and meaning in life.

The world… I learned the world isn't always kind. There's a lot of judgment and prejudice out there. But there's also a lot of compassion and understanding. And it's up to us to choose which one we focus on.

This whole experience changed me. It made me more mature, more compassionate, and more resilient. It forced me to confront my own beliefs and values. And it helped me to figure out who I am and what I want out of life.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. Because it made me who I am today. And I'm okay with that. I'm actually… pretty proud of who I am. Even with all my flaws and imperfections. It's been a journey, and I'm still figuring things out. But I'm getting there. And that's all that matters.

(Sighs, a long, thoughtful one) Okay. That's… a hard question. It's easy to look back and say, "I should have done this," or "I shouldn't have done that." But honestly? I don't know if I would have changed much.

Maybe I would have talked to my dad sooner. I was so scared to tell him, and I think that made things harder on everyone. But I was also really young and really confused.

Maybe I would have been more open with Leah from the beginning. I let my fear of judgment get in the way of our friendship, and I regret that.

But ultimately, I think everything happened the way it was supposed to. It was a messy, complicated, and sometimes painful experience, but it made me who I am today.

I learned a lot about myself. I learned about strength, and resilience, and compassion. I learned about the importance of family and friends. And I learned about the power of making difficult decisions.

I think if I had changed anything, I might not have learned those lessons. I might not have grown as a person.

So, no. I don't think I would have done anything differently. Not really.

I mean, sure, I wish things had been easier. I wish I hadn't had to go through so much pain and uncertainty. But I also know that those experiences made me stronger.

And I'm grateful for the people who supported me along the way. Bren, my dad, Mark and Vanessa… they all helped me to get through it.

So yeah. I wouldn't change a thing. It was a difficult journey, but it was my journey. And I'm proud of the person I've become. Even if I'm still a little bit sarcastic and cynical. Some things never change, right? But underneath it all, I think I'm okay. More than okay, actually. I'm… hopeful. And that's a good feeling. A really good feeling.

Ugh, disappointment. It's like my constant companion, honestly. Things rarely go as planned, and I've had to learn to deal with it. It's not pretty, at first.

My first reaction is usually to be sarcastic. Like, "Oh, great. Just *perfect*. Exactly how I envisioned things." It's a defense mechanism, I guess. A way to deflect the pain.

Then, I usually feel a little bit sorry for myself. I mope around, listen to sad music, and eat a lot of junk food. It's not healthy, but it helps me to process my emotions.

But eventually, I realize that wallowing in self-pity isn't going to solve anything. So I try to reframe the situation. I try to look at it from a different perspective.

I ask myself, "What can I learn from this?" "What can I do differently next time?" "Is this really the end of the world?"

And usually, the answer is no. It's not the end of the world. It's just a setback. A bump in the road.

I also try to focus on the things that are going well in my life. Even when things are tough, there's always something to be grateful for.

And I talk to Bren. She's really good at helping me to see the silver lining. She reminds me that I'm strong and capable, and that I can handle anything.

It's not easy. It takes time and effort. But I'm learning to accept that disappointment is a part of life. And I'm learning to cope with it in a healthy way.

So yeah. Sarcasm, self-pity, reframing, gratitude, and talking to Bren. That's my strategy for dealing with disappointment. It's not perfect, but it works. And it reminds me that even when things don't go as planned, I can still keep going. I can still find a way to be happy. And that's what matters.

Ugh, don't make me relive that. It still stings a little, honestly.

Okay, so at the beginning of the movie, Leah and I were *inseparable*. We did everything together. We talked about everything. She was my person. My best friend. We were, like, a unit.

But then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

I think she was scared. She didn't know how to react. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. She started to hang out with other people. She stopped calling as much.

I think she was afraid of what my pregnancy would mean for our friendship. She was afraid of being associated with it. She was afraid of being judged.

And I was angry. I was angry that she wasn't being more supportive. I was angry that she was abandoning me when I needed her the most.

We had a huge fight at the arcade. I said some really mean things. And she said some really mean things. It was awful.

After that, we didn't talk for a while. I was heartbroken. I felt like I had lost my best friend.

But then, eventually, we started to talk again. Slowly. Tentatively.

She came to the adoption meeting with me. And she apologized. And I apologized too.

We realized that we had both been hurting. And that we had both been scared.

Our friendship didn't go back to exactly the way it was before. It was different. More mature. More complicated.

But it was still a friendship. And it was still important to me.

It evolved from being a carefree, all-consuming friendship to something more… realistic. Something that could withstand challenges and changes.

It taught me that friendships aren't always easy. And that sometimes, people grow apart. But it also taught me that true friends will always find a way to come back to each other. Even if it takes time.

So yeah. Our friendship evolved. It wasn't perfect. But it was real. And that's what mattered. It was a messy, complicated, beautiful evolution. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the arcade fight. Okay, maybe I'd trade the arcade fight. But still. It was important.

(Sighs, then a small smile) Okay, wow. That's… a surprisingly hard question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Morning sickness, weird cravings, the constant worry… it wasn't all rainbows and butterflies.

But if I had to pick a favorite part… it was feeling the baby kick.

Seriously. It sounds cliché, I know. But it was incredible.

At first, it was just little flutters, like butterflies in my stomach. And then, as the months went on, the kicks got stronger and more frequent.

It was a reminder that there was a tiny human being growing inside of me. A little person who was depending on me.

And it was a really powerful feeling. It made me feel connected to the baby in a way that I never thought possible.

It was also a little bit weird. Like, sometimes the baby would kick me really hard, and it would take my breath away. And I'd talk to it, and tell it to be gentle.

But mostly, it was just… amazing. It was a reminder that even in the midst of all the chaos and uncertainty, there was something beautiful and miraculous happening.

It was a feeling of hope. A feeling of love. A feeling of… wonder.

It was the one part of being pregnant that I truly enjoyed. And it's a memory that I'll cherish forever. It was a reminder that even though I was giving the baby up for adoption, I would always be connected to him or her. And that's a pretty special feeling. It really is.
